So much no here. 8 billion humans is already horrifying, imagining such astronomical numbers of humans is beyond depressing. People are happy with space around them, the natural world, and a small number of others they know well. When local people are responsible for the land, they have a vested interest in looking after the place. Global scale management removes accountability and personal concern for things being done well, and greed and selfish interests rule the world. Cities are hell holes of mental illness and crime, and people flee them for more spacious, natural places. Our innovations, while clever, are destroying the environment. Where can you find a natural source of freshwater near you? Chances are very high that without the town water supply, there is NO drinkable water near you. All the waterways are polluted. We are filling the earth with plastics, PFAS/"forever chemicals", nuclear waste and heavens knows what else, instead of the trees and plants and clean, fresh water that have been here for eons of time. We are using up all the non-renewable resources at a breathtaking rate. We are populating every nook and cranny of the planet, and that means there is less and less room for the things that we like to have around us, the natural world. Fighting over land, water, food and other resources can only intensify as the crowding increases. I could go on, but we are all so familiar with the problems. We are hurtling toward a brick wall. How could anyone possibly cheer themselves by imagining that more of all of this is a good thing?

This has a weirdly pro-life philosophy. Why do “unborn” lives matter? Why should we ever make decisions based on potential lives?

The video makes an assumption that life is good and therefore we should try to maximize the number of future people. I find that a very strange position.

I think life matters, and the living matter, and we should make the world better for the living and the lives the living want to bring into the world. But abstracting this into some intrinsic value of “unborn life” is utterly ridiculous.

I routinely think about how young the human race really is. We've come a long ways from the stone age, yes. But humans haven't even scratched the surface of an advanced society yet. We are as much a relic living today as we view our ancestors that made tools from wood and stone. I'm very thankful to have experienced life, but I am left melancholic knowing I will miss out on the biggest parts of human evolution, revolution, history, expansion, exploration and the gained knowledge that will be uncovered if our race lives for another million years. In this aspect I'd rather live at the end knowing all that ever was than in the beginning and wondering all that ever could be.

This assumes that we don’t kill ourselves off with the falling birth rates from the “It’s all about me” movement.

But why should we keep having an idea that proper of human being is right thing? Future is uncertain and people usually regards uncertainty as optimism, like "A huge meteor will strike the earth in the future but maybe we can protect ourselves from it". The dark side of uncertainty is usually ignored. There is and will be always possibility that our hopes fail. We couldn't destroy the meteor, couldn't avoid gamma-ray burst, couldn't prevent the nuclear world war3, and couldn't succeed in cutting out CO2 emission.  The bad things which brings extinction of us is always possible to become reality. It's reckless that humanity will face good side of uncertainty forever. It's a very simple truth. It's nothing more than casino games, undeniable principle of probability. And the best way at casino is leaving there when you are not bankrupt yet. Humanity has only two options for its future. Stop birth to die out in peace or keep birth then killed off by disaster. So which one we should choose?  Is it really right thing that humanity continues to have next generations?

Right, as if 7 billion are not causing enough damage to themselves and the environment, let's go for quadrillion. Dystopia would be inevitable in those numbers. I'd much rather we stick to our current population (or less) but grow in wisdom. That's a future I could aspire to build. Less is more.

If you've enjoyed this video, I highly recommend The Beginning of Infinity by David Deutsch. He argues vehemently for this exact kind of optimism. We are knowledge creators, and all physically possible transformations can be performed with the requisite knowledge. Optimism is not an attitude, like glass half full, but a fact about the universe. Specifically, although problems are inevitable, they can also be solved! There is no problem blocking our path to this future that cannot be solved in principle. We must lean into progress, creativity, and knowledge creation. Read the book!

Optimism and pessimism are both ideologies. Ideologies function as filters that cause one to select or dismiss evidence that confirms one's ideology. Realism is an approach that compels one to consider all evidence and to place it into a comprehensive whole. OMG. ALL of this crap is overly optimistic. Basing trillions more human beings on space travel, when we can't even get back to the Moon. Even the 1972 MIT Limits to Growth study (their "Business as Usual" scenario) put the peak in human population around the middle of this century. And it gets better: Recently updated versions of The Limits to Growth study have the fun starting even sooner.

We hit 4.5 - 5 deg. C global average temperature by 2100. Problem is, we probably already lost our civilization at 2 deg. C above pre-industrial baseline, due to heat waves and the inability to grow food at scale (just look at the global disruption caused by two half-assed Slavic countries' militaries fighting each other).

Population overshoot, Climate Change and resource depletion are going to destroy this global civilization within our lifetimes.

Have a nice day.

Now look at us, 3.7 billion years later, on a planet covered with life, with so much diversity and so many species lost forever.. asking ourselves "Are we alone? Is there life on another planets?"

The most important question this proposes is, what is human? Is human the biological entity or the consciousness that lies within? If human is the biological, then this scenario makes sense. However, if human is the consciousness, then the number of humans does not matter. The only thing that matters is that the consciousness remains and continues to experience.

Consciousness is a result of the universe itself. Consciousnesses goal appears to be experiencing itself subjectively. While many humans gives that consciousness many paths to experience, a variety of experience may be more preferable to a universal consciousness. It comes down to the old adage of, "wouldn't it be boring if everyone was the same?" To this end, I don't think that any form of universal consciousness would allow its physical expression to become so limited as to be only expressed through the human form.

The authors are optimistic! I totally agree. Perhaps more realistic and also equally exciting (if framed properly):
There's been about 100 billion of us. There will probably be about 100 billion more. That will be it.

A key takeaway from the authors here (particularly from 4:30): for all of this to be true, we'd have to be part of the lucky <1% of humans that exist at the very BEGINNING, so there's a >99% that NONE of this will come true.

The author is correct in calling this "optimistic" in how unlikely these projections are, but perhaps not quite right about the level of uncertainty considering >99% is a low uncertainty.

Once you start talking about leaving earth, it just gets dumb. We have no good reason to suspect this is possible. Just hand waving the obstacles away by pointing out there's plenty of water and "materials" out in the solar system doesn't scratch the surface of how unrealistic this idea is. Just getting out there requires use of massive amounts of resources, all of which need to come from earth, and none of which can realistically be spared for such a venture.

"we can change the direction of planet killer asteroids" Um, not really. It's within our grasp, but as of right now, any planet killing asteroid avoidance is still aspirational. The problem is we don't have anything built that is ready to go, and the timescale for building such devices exceed the likely warning time we get. That's assuming we could even get everyone to agree that it's a problem we need to address, which isn't a certainty anymore.

I Have a Theory
My theory is that the way we all experience the world is unequal and different.
Here's my proof.

We are all mentally different in a way. We have different IQ levels, skills, hobbies, etc. Despite all these differences, we all have the five senses. They are seeing, hearing, smelling, tasting, and touching. All these senses are messages sent to the brain. The brain is a very different organ for everyone.

These senses may work differently for everyone. Some people way have these senses work more similarly, while other people have them work more differently. Here's an example of how this theory works. I see the grass as green, while someone else might see the grass as blue. And if I say, "The grass is green." they might hear me say, "The grass is blue.".

Here're some other examples.

-New words to the dictionary
-Removed words from the dictionary
-Replaced words in the dictionary
-Cities, Countries, Continents, Planets, Stars, and Galaxies with new names
-Countries with different shaped borders
-Country flags with different patterns and colors
-Animals and Plants are different colors
-Animals make different sounds
-measuring systems work differently
-clock systems work differently
-people look different from how you see them

And that was my theory.

it's mind blowing to think of all the things we have acomplished yet we are only 1/5th of the way in to our specie's exsistance ( even less percentage in if our species goes on for 10 million years instead of 1 million). this is assuming we are not even lower on the averages. keep in mind how an average is obtained , you total the numbers then divide them by how many you are totaling and that is your average. some species live quite a bit less than 1 milion years.

example: 6 kids turn in their test papers and the teacher grades them as so 20 + 100 + 59 + 89 + 37 + 92 = 397
397 / 6 = 66.16666 rounding off you can say the class got an average test grade of 66. teha verage doesn't tell you that 3 kids got very high passing grades , while 1 got a middle range failing grade and two others got abysmal fails. Point is some one has to be the failing grades to make that average 66 . Are we (humans) going to be one of the abyssal failing grades, one of the super passing grades, or just the guy that made it half way.

Telling me the average mammal species goes extinct after 1 million years while some lasted as long as 10 million , actually makes me more worried not more optimistic. because 99.99% of all life that has ever exisited (on earth) is catogorized as extinct. that means for every mammal species that lasted 10 million years , there had to be thousands of species that didn't even make it to 1 million for the average to be 1 million. though you could say there also had to be thousands of species that made it above 1 million, but with the highest rate being 10 milion and the average being so low in comparison at 1 mill, there's clearly more species that die younger than ones that die older. Also the margin for error is just too high for us as a species to take that average for granted. Especially with every thing going on in the last 60 years. that average wouldn't budge one decimal if Humans disappeared toworrow, the average would still be 1 million years. And that is what scares me about this whole topic. We can't and shouldn't take comfort from such a low average when we knwo the planet has seen an almost uncountable number of mammal species of which the vast majority are already extinct today.

Fun to think, but ultimately driven by emotion. If people don't care about the now, it means they don't really care for each other. You might be able to argue that it's easier to care about the faceless of the future, but logically, philosophically, there's no reason to care about them more or less than the people that exist today. If you think this sounds doomer, you haven't kept up already! It's neutral at best. But it shows that feeling good about it was emotionally driven. By the video, by the music, by the sound of his voice. The argument is not that it's impossible to find good in the future, that would be you not keeping up again. It's not impossible to find good now, is it? Of course not. But it's the same - that's the assertion. That's why the cloud looms over your heads. I've simply put it into words. So what should you do? The same you always have: a mix of what you have to and what you want to, with the mystery toppings best represented as whatever set of temporal rules that society governs with at the time. They put as much pressure on what you want and have to do as you do with your own mind, and the combination of these things ends up creating the vast majority your life's timeline.

But I digress. Why would anyone care about the faceless future more than a faceless person from another state or country? They wouldn't. That's why the cloud remains.

Nice video. It brought up some other philosophical questions for me:

1. Why care about humans, specifically? This anthropocentric view seems arbitrarily biased. What if the thing that matters most is consciousness itself, and there are many more possible form factors capable of consciousness (many other species already in existence, plus near infinite amount yet to come).

2. What if, instead of assuming the goal of improving the quality of life for all of the future unborn people, we assume the goal of improving the quality of life for ourselves? I'll admit focusing on ourselves seems to be the status quo, but is it a bad approach? In a sense it is democratizing the effort of improving the quality of life for all beings. We develop medicines because we and our loved ones suffer from disease. We protect the environment because we fear for our lives and our immediate children's lives. Far future generations potentially get to take advantage of this progress without us explicitly planning for it.

There is no one answer to these questions since they depend on a number of factors, including changes in technology, culture, and the environment. However, we can make some educated guesses. The last human is likely to be born sometime in the next few hundred years. The number of people who will ever be born is difficult to estimate, but it is likely to be in the range of a few trillion.
These numbers may seem small, but they are actually quite significant. In the grand scheme of things, humanity is a very young species. We have only been around for a few hundred thousand years. In comparison, the universe is around 14 billion years old and the Earth is 4.5 billion years old.
This means that the lifetime of humanity is only a tiny fraction of the lifetime of the universe or the Earth. In fact, if we take the lifetime of the universe and divide it by the number of people who will ever be born, we get an average lifetime of around 200 million years. This is an unimaginably long time.
The universe is billions of years old and humanity is only a fraction of that. We have an unimaginably long time to create the best world for ourselves. Let's focus on the future and not the apocalyptic end times that some people seem obsessed with.

Here is the 1st part of the Proof to the Collatz conjecture which absolutely proves there is only one possible way in in any one sequence so no loop is possible, simplified as simple and clear as can be, as tight as and explained as simply as Euclids proof to the primes though it does have more factors. The other half is on the collatzconjectureproof page on my website which I'm sure you know by now. If not it is linked in every video on my channel.

In the proof to the Collatz conjecture we use 3 types of odd numbers


A number divisible by 3 (3n) 9,15,2, 27 etc


A 3n+2 11,17, 23, 29...etc


A 3n-2 13, 19, 25, 31...etc




When we do this we spot a pattern.


1. Every division by 2^odd number (2,8,32,128 etc) leads to a 2+1


2. Every division by 2^even number leads to a 2-1.




3. There are 2 functions which lead to the same stop-start value of x only 1234 can satisfy both functions simultaneously.


3x+1÷2^n


3x+1/3÷2^n


Some 2 separate numbers can together satisfy both functions to arrive at the same stop-start number but they cannot be in the same sequence.




Because


For a loop there must be 2 ways in and one way out. This is not possible.


4. A number can have 2 ways in and one way out for example 47 can be reached by 31×3+1÷2 or by 125×3+1÷8 but the 2 ways in cannot happen in the same sequence.


4a. Because both come from an initial number that must be part of the sequence, for example 27 is the starting x which leads to the number 31×3+1÷2=47 but 27 is divisible by 3 so cannot be the arrived at by a descent from 3x+1÷2. 97 is a 3n-2 which cannot be descended into from above because.


4b. A starting x that is a 3n-2 cannot be descended into from above because in order for a 3n-2 to be arrived at by the function 3x+1÷2 it must be arrived at from below because any (3n-2)×3+1÷2 can only happen where that 3n-2 is a lower value than the initial x because in order to arrive at the same slope between x and 2x it must also satisfy the slope between x and 4x (3x+1/3) in a direct descent so therefore any 3n-2 must arrive at most at 2x. So therefore such stop start number would be a 3n+2. If it is a 3n+2 then 2x must at most be 1/2 of 1/4 of 8x which has the same slope as between x and 2x relative to 0 but this is impossible because then the 8x would be 16x relative to the stop start number which is impossible because all divisions by 2^even number (base 4) end in a 3n-2.  ￼


So there can be no descent from higher up it must come from below. There cannot be any number within infinity that can satisfy this requirement because the 1st number to violate the descent to 1234 must theoretically come from above (which I have just shown is impossible) not below because all lower numbers would have already decended to 1234.


4c. No 2 different 3n+2 can descend at the same slope to arrive at the initial value of X see illustration attached.


No 2 3n+2 numbers can both satisfy the same end number after 3x+1÷2^n because any 2 numbers satisfying the function descend at a different slope relative to a direct line to 0 so cannot both arrive at the same slope that is between x and 2x in a direct descent.  So any initial x must have been arrived at from only one possible route, a sequence which must begin at the initial value of x (or lower which as already established is impossible because the theorised 1st number to violate the drop to 1234 cannot be arrived at from below). Also because for any theoretical slope to arrive at the stop-start x which is a 3n+2 it must satisfy 3x+1÷2 from (a) a lower value of x which must have been arrived at from operations of the function beginning at the initial x which means a descent from a higher value of 3x+1 also is impossible because then it cannot also satisfy the function 3x+1/3 to descend into the same slope between 2x and x. If it did arrive from higher it cannot also arrive from lower which is obvious but may not be obvious to anyone under stress.


So no loop is possible arising from any number within infinity for these simple reasons. The Collatz conjecture absolutely definitely cannot have a loop.

Not to be that guy, but I feel like if the species is to have any chance surviving even a thousand years into the future, with the world-ending capabilities we have, and our affinity for infighting, then we simply MUST figure out a way to abandon our competitive tendencies for cooperative ones. Because an individual accomplishes nothing, and is practically useless. You could not birth yourself, or raise yourself, or feed yourself. We all rely on the work of millions, and the millions rely on each other. Even the bench you sit on at the park was created by someone in the past. The idea you have in that park, facilitated by that bench, belongs partially, in spirit, to the worker who made it. Society gives and society creates, yet we take violent possession of these things for ourselves, pretending that a colossal effort on the part of many people wasn't what gave rise to the creation or maintenance of anything, particularly the anythings that individuals love to take private ownership of.

This means that the future imagined in this video, in my opinion, is likely a future without Capitalism. Truly optimistic indeed. It is easier to imagine the end of the world than it is to imagine the end of Capitalism. Science fiction writers hardly create anything other than hyper-capitalist futures, disregarding the historical unlikelihood of Capitalism's continued proliferation in as little as even just a century in the future. Capitalism is regularly our biggest obstacle to many things. And hell, say what you will about the Soviets, but they practically won the space race.

Whatever the way forward is, I feel pretty confident that it has to do with throwing off this exploitative system, for something better, more ethical, more humane. A better world is possible. And it all hinges on us realising that, and creating it. It doesn't come from nothing. We need to make it happen. Hope is not enough.

Yeah, right. For now, let’s focus on preserving humanity from the effects of the great energetic, food and material descent that it will face over the next 50 years. We will see about surviving 800,000 more years or colonising space when we finally understand how to grow within limits.

An honest appraisal of the Drake equation suggests we may be the only intelligent life in the universe (The fluke of photosynthesis being part of the reason) so we really need to survive somehow.
Biological humans will not survive interstellar travel unless we travel in a totally self sufficient (including pseudo gravity) environment which would render traveling pointless in the first place due to the thousands of years and hundreds of generations just to get anywhere. We'd be a different species by the time we arrived.
The earth has about six billion years left before the sun consumes it and dies so what to do?
We need to export our consciousness into some form of indestructible storage system that can be dispatched around the galaxy to seed star systems with life and our knowledge to guide it.
In short, we will become gods.
In the mean time we should look after the earth as we are the custodians of this tiny little blue green oasis of life in an otherwise barren universe.

the ideia is a little more complex than that. It's not just abundance of resources equal to free exponencial growth. We doesn't need just these three things to exist (surface, resources, energy). We are a species in a food chain and interdependent from almost all other life on this planet, including the realm of bacterias. We are protected against the harms of open space by a delicate balance among magnetic fields, ozone layers and oxygen/carbon/nitrogen cycles. Species naturally splits into sub-species, compete each other and some genetic streams prevails over weak or non-expressive ones, genetic mutations are essencial not only for evolution, but for survival and adaptation to environmental changes. All these potencial trillions of trillions of future "human lives" probably aren't humans at all, but future potencial members of new species we dont even imagine yet, that will evolve from us, some maybe so different as we are from the first primates millions of years ago.

It is interesting to see that the dinosaurs lived a hundred million years and probably never developed intelligence. They just didn't need that.
They lived in a dinosaur's paradise where birth control was provided by the environment. We could say that they were safely controlled by their environment - they couldn't get to a situation where they do anything that makes them extinct.
Humans have passed that line a long time ago... er, well, in that scale, not so long time ago. We can potentially make the earth inhabitable in a few days, and we're continually making it inhabitable by transforming it slowly.
Moreover, we have long passed a sustainable population. We have made most other animals and plants extinct, and our population is barely sustainable in this globalized world. One local war and millions starve. Any advance in technology, or logistics is instantly used up to support new population - to the point that the population makes the environment toxic for everyone.
I also can't support the vision of the population peaking at 11,5 billion - that would require everyone becoming rich enough that the number of children decreases. What I see is these rich people dying out, and overpopulated people flowing to their place. This way the increase never stops, it will keep its exponential nature.
This doesn't mean that Humanity is doomed. It only means that it needs to learn. It might need a few iterations. Most of the above problems doesn't mean the end of the human race - only the decimation of the population. Still, I really hope that I won't be alive to see it. Maybe in a thousand years this whole mess will seem like a minor hiccup on the way of Humanity becoming an interstellar race. We'll see. Or, rather, we won't. :)

John S. Lewis From 'Mining the Sky':
As long as the human population remains as pitifully small as it is today, we shall be severely limited in what we can accomplish. Human intelligence is the key to the future: human beings are not, as some would have it, a form of pollution.
Having only one Einstein, one Hokusai, one Mozart, one daVinci, one Shankara,... is not enough. We need (and can have) a million times as many. We need intelligence, wisdom, compassion, and excellence. These godlike traits are manifested in the physical universe only by life, and in the biological universe, only by intelligent life.
Life is not a cancer of matter; it is matter's trancendance of itself. The fulfillment of time & space is matter; the fulfillment of matter is life; the highest fulfillment of life is unbounded intelligence & compassion.
We would be quite wrong to conclude that the asteroid belt, or solar power... is the ultimate resource. Intelligent life, once liberated by the resources of space, is the greatest resource of the solar system. The material and energy resources of the solar system allow mankind an infinite future: we can not only break free of the surly bonds of the Earth, but break free of the Sun and escape its fate.
"There is no way back into the past. The choice is the universe or nothing." - H.G. Wells

Freeman Dyson said that "not one species, nor a billion" will exhaust the new niches awaiting life which we can bring. He wrote that there's no real reason why we shouldn't live on past the end of the Sun.
He also said that we might find ourselves in the position one day to do something about the ultimate end of the ability of the universe to support life, whether it's the "heat death" or a "cold death" from continuing expansion, as seems to be the case.
See his article "Time Without End: Physics and Biology in an Open Universe". He openly challenges how nobody seems to want to look into the deep future and what prospects might await. He gives a round number of 10^10^76 years, for life to persist.

"While civilization is more than a high material living standard it is nevertheless based on material abundance. It does not thrive on abject poverty or in an atmosphere of resignation and hopelessness. Therefore, the end objectives of solar system exploration are social objectives, in the sense that they relate to or are dictated by present and future human needs." – Lunar visionary Kraft Ehricke, 1970

Humans have only been around for ~200k years. Things like us, maybe a million.

There's no reason to think that anyone a half billion years in the future will want to tinker themselves or their offspring to be like us Mk-1 humans.
The human species will go extinct, when among the billion species of sentient life from here spread across the galaxy, none are "human" any more.

I point out that the O'Neill space colony came about because O'Neill at Stanford, was tired of the doom and gloom and popular sentiment that technology only kills and can never actually make things better.
He challenged a class of grad & undergrad students to find something for a long term hopeful future in high technology, and after looking at what Apollo was bringing back from the moon, gradually hammered it out to the extent that NASA Ames and Stanford ran the '70s space settlement studies. They found that there are no new inventions needed to mine asteroids or moons and to build for virtually Earth-like conditions anywhere in space where there are or to which we bring materials.

Note that doing so would destroy "money" or "wealth" as we know it. The first entity that returns from an NEA, even a few kg of loosely sorted metals, instantly and forever wins the "game" of making money from collecting resources of raw materials, or energy (or monetary metals).
Within 50 years from start, any time since the '70s we've wanted to start, we'd end the relevance of the scarcity model to raw materials or energy or room for growth.
Construction materials are literally raining down on us. The little Apollo class NEA that hit near Chelyabinsk in '13 was denser with metals than Earth's crust ~50km deep. Some meteorites ae density 8+, greater than pure Iron. King Tut's rust-proof meteoritic steel dagger is 6% cobalt. No mine on a moon or planet will ever work such materials.
We know of 1400 NEAs more easily accessible (and year-round) than Mars. 400 easier than the Moon, 40 or so easier than Lunar orbit. The Apollo capsules came straight in on hyperbolic interplanetary trajectories without entering orbit or trying to slow down. An aeroentry barge of asteroid materials doesn't even need to stay intact or afloat after splashing down in the shallows off an industrial port city.

O'Neill and NASA showed this to Congress back then. Obviously the "powers that be" back then thought that a better future for us now would be stuck down here, in pollution and oil wars.
Note that for the cost of ~3 of our CVNs and their air wing and escorts and the logistics infrastructure to deploy them to fight over oil, we could have started mining and building in space and had the first small, first-generation space habitat and all the ground and in-space infrastructure to reproduce it.
The "Cost" would since have been paid off along with the national debt, by asteroidal metals. No more oil wars or budget shortfalls, ever.

Yes, I know many will say that asteroidal metals can never be economically brought back.
As with space colonies themselves or Solar power satellites, such objections always overlook the scale of the resource, and assume many straw-men to make it impossible.
All, even "futurists" (even O'Neill), shy away violently from thoughts of crashing the value of all the gold in all the vaults, or the oil underground. We just don't dare think about such a thing. Why? we just don't.
So we're left with trying to dream up ways a colony or space effort can pay for itself. Zubrin talks about patent royalties for things invented by Mars colonists. Musk sells internet and ground-orbit launch services, to pay for going into space.

I like to point out that the biggest hoax and scam of the space age is that so many have been convinced that doing things in space is and must be a huge, budget-busting expense, and that there's nothing worth going on for, or doing in space.
Both are simply not true.
During Apollo, the US spent as much on cosmetics, and large States spent more on liquor, then we spent going to the Moon.
The bailouts of '08 were greater than the entire historic running grand total NASA expense. Including Apollo, the Shuttle and ISS. The bailouts of 2020 very much more.
Today our annual DoD budget is ~80% of that running total NASA cost. Not counting "black" military budgets and on-gong military operational expenses, which aren't included in that voted DoD budget but are tacked on as "riders" in "must-pass" legislation. During our invasion of Iraq, we were spending $8 billion a month, and our NASA budget was $17 billion.
Today, we spend more on each: fast foods, illegal drugs, sports gambling, and lotteries, as on NASA.

This is oddly unscientific and irresponsible analysis. For example, by watching the video the viewer will get the sens that in scenario 1 (humans never leaving earth) with even a pessimistic estimate humans will survive 800 thousand more years, and the rationale for this is how long the homo-erectus and other mammals survived, which oddly doesn't factor in the difference between humans and the mammals before us, mainly, how much we change our environment and at an extremely acceleration rate. So while the video essay communicates that 800 thousand more years of humans is a pessimistic estimate, scientific thinking does not permit such gross assumptions and misguided analysis. And that's just about scenario 1. The whole video is full of assumptions that are coated in misinformation. Of course assumptions are often necessary in most analysis, and the narrator acknowledges that these are assumptions. But the problem is in the fact that the video misguides the viewer on the nature of these assumptions; in my example, while the assumption is an overtly optimistic and simplelistic estimate, the narrator communicates that the estimate is a pesimistic and conservative one. Really disappointing video by such great channel.

Sorry to be the wet blanket on this wildly optimistic video, but there is a probabilistic argument for how human civilization will progress, and it is not nearly so rosy:

Suppose you have an equal probability of having been born as any person in the history of humanity. 117 billion people have come before us. With this prior information we can calculate a probability function for the total number of humans who will ever exist, which averages out to 234 billion humans. With these assumptions, it is likely that there will be a great die off within the next 1000 years or so, after which humanity will return to it's preindustrial numbers

People have witnessed what was for them the end of their world. E.g. many theologically minded people saw the philosophy of Kant (nicknamed ‘the All-destroyer’) as a veritable apocalypse. AND IT WAS. That is precisely human history; that we can suffer the end of the world, and span the present and its total contradiction.

This video seems to suggest (very much in line with its scientistic faith) that we should think of human history as a straight uninterrupted line. This is the most reactionary conservatism, the most backward thinking. Nothing happens in the belief that the future is visible and at our disposal. In the contrary view, that the future cannot be imaged or conceived under current concepts and desires, means that the coming of the future makes a real apocalypse, the end of everything we know. This radical break which makes history itself justifies and makes necessary apocalyptic thinking. Yes. You do live in the end times, and if we survive this apocalypse, the future wont look anything like the animations in this video, or anything our scientists can speculate about.

But wait...if it was very likely that we might become a galactic civilization and last for 10 billion years, then where are the aliens doing what this video describes us as potentially doing? The kind of technologies needed to expand across the solar system and then to expand across the galaxy become exponentially less likely, because the distances they need to span become exponentially larger. This makes an exponential growth rate of human population implausible.

If these magical travel technologies do exist, then another problem future humans will encounter is competition with other species for the desirable worlds of the galaxy. Such competition can reduce our expansion rate to 0 as easily as reaching earth's carrying capacity will do.

I would never publish a guess at our future expansion rate that was faster than linear in the long run, and even that seems far-fetched.

I'd argue that longtermism (i.e. the idea of treating contributions to any present and future periods of society equally) also favors the longevity of individual humans, if you assume that there is at least a small chance that the idea of "longevity escape velocity", i.e. longevity interventions coming out faster than the rate of aging, can be reached in your lifetime.

My argument is that if YOU want to do the most help you can to the world in the future, you should spend the first 100 years of your life on making yourself ageless through researching longevity technology or doing something else to assist the field. This means there is a chance that you will not die after about 100 years whereas otherwise you would've. Even if there is a very high chance you fail, on the off-chance that you succeed, it will dramatically increase how long you live and thus your total positive contribution to civilization, provided that the one average person you're "replacing" by becoming ageless and consuming society's resources is not expected to contribute as much.

Of course there is a counterargument to this, that maybe the other people that become ageless due to your intervention are, on average, less willing to help the world long-term than if longevity had developed later without your effort. These people will all live for a very long time too, so if they make fewer long-term contributions, it would drown out the positive effects of yourself surviving. So it might be better to get as much as possible of the society acquainted with the idea of longevity and long-term thinking first before introducing such a scientific breakthrough.

The main issue isn't even with things like staying on Earth or leaving Earth, but rather what the definition of human (and "born") is.

Digitized life is on the visible-but-distant horizon, and synthetic biological genetically-intentional (fully engineered) organisms are on a similar track, although I'm guessing a bit further off. At that sort of point new consciousnesses could pop up but they wouldn't have a heritage of being human. Human-like AIs would also not be human, although current people will not realize why we would potentially even consider such an AI to be human. The reason being is that if you perfectly emulate a human brain digitally, that will be an AI, but it will also be a human mind, so in that sense they would be just as human as a digitized consciousness of a biological human. Such AIs could also be given biological (or non-biological) bodies given sufficient technology; sort of like "Westworld".

I guess the video gets into that topic a little bit later, after the point where I wrote this.

It's 2am on a Monday morning.  I was about to make a comment that I would come and be optimized at a more appropriate time, Monday mornings being what they are.  Somehow, however, the optimism found a crack in my rough exterior and it occurred to me that maybe my whole life is a Monday morning, we are all living a Monday morning.  As depressing and tough as it is, if we can just get up, get a cup of coffee and a shower and tackle the commute to the office then we've got a fighting chance to succeed.  We'll have gotten the toughest part out of the way.  Our grandkids will still have a tough go of it, Monday morning meetings, but there may be doughnuts, their grandkids will get to enjoy lunch while going over expense reports, but with each generation it'll get easier. Hump day will find our 30ith removed great grandkids making plans for their future great, great, great grandkids and TGIF.  All we got to do is clean up and make it through the Monday morning commute.

Within The Optimistic Habitable Zone of our Solar System is Earth, Earth's Moon, Mars, and Maybe Venus. Improving Habitability of these places and building infrastructure on and between them (e.g. O'neil Colonies, space elevators, mass drivers, basic Terraformation such as giving Mars oceans & Atmosphere from Ganymede/Callisto/Europa/Titan and Depressurizing Venus by removing atmosphere, etc...) should & will be our inevitable long-term goals for the forseeable future of humanity.

I love Kurzgesagt, but I'd like to paint a different picture for the future. First, I'll say please read this comment to the end, or you will have nightmares.
Okay, here goes.
The last biological human will be born a few centuries from now. At that time, there will be alive many hundreds of billions of non-biological people, all of whom live within virtual worlds and/or robotic bodies (and can move between the two at will). All (or almost all) of these virtual worlds will exist in spaceships, some of which have a permanent place within the solar system, and some of which are on a long journey to another star. However, and this is the bit which is difficult to explain, humanity is also on a long journey towards evolving into something else. That 'something' has cognition, just like us, but it probably cannot be divided into individuals. Rather, it is a gestalt entity, with thoughts that can swirl separately for a while and then join in with the others without barriers. The way it thinks, its instincts and goals, it cognitive abilities, are evolving from those of humans, but are destined to become very different.
I believe humanity will survive. History shows that, as a species, we are very good survivors. There may be calamities which kill many people in the future. But some people, at least, will survive.
However, we are not going to stand still. Our technology will evolve. We will evolve. What we become in the future may well be unrecognisable and scary to us now.
But what we become will, I believe, actually be a better us. We are held down by our biological limitations and anachronistic instincts. Future us will be better. Still flawed, still making mistakes, but nevertheless better.
It can be very hard to accept the idea that we will evolve into something that is alien to how we are now, but remember that a new born baby evolves into something very alien to what it is at birth: an adult human. In the same way, we, humanity, will necessarily evolve into something very different in the future. But that is good, and right.

Unintelligent* mammals may have an average lifespan of 1 million years. This model isn't applicable to intelligent agents such as humans, who, as a direct result of their intelligence, generate exponential growth scenarios (such as the industrial revolution).

So using the average mammalian lifespan model isn't very valid to humans. At our current rate of progression, we may exist for another 100, 1000, 10000 years etc before we reach some kind of great filter.

It's very difficult to make an accurate model of human progression, since this is a relatively new phenomenon.

This argument presented in this video is flawed as it's built upon a poor foundation. The "0.008%" figure was derived from the initial, invalid comparison between average mammalian lifespan and the potential human lifespan. We may be at the end of our journey, there is simply not enough data to reach any conclusive answer.

*I'm defining unintelligent mammals as those that are incapable of intelligent thought and reasoning (like mammoths).

The whole point of the n-llion system is to replace how many times "million" is repeated with a suffix, thus:
a million million - twice - bi - billion
a million million million - three times - tri - trillion
a million million million million - four times - quadri - quadrillion

The way you talk about future generations sounds quite irrational to me. You're almost literally presenting it as though there existed an actual, divine que of people waiting and wanting to be born. Those awaiting their birth could then supposedly be stripped of that chance by us if for example we led to the "premature" extinction of our species. But that doesn't make sense and seems like magical thinking. Potential people is just a concept in our heads, they don't exist in any meaningful way, can't be harmed and they have no wishes or volition of any sort. This is the same logic anti choice people use when arguing against abortions, they say a fetus perhaps doesn't have a consciousness or a brain but it can develop into a thinking human being so if we kill it now, we're hurting that potential human being that would later develop.

Thinking about the future is important but stop making it sound as though, in case we blow ourselves up for example, there will be some magical "potential humans" complaining about our failure to give them a chance to be born.

Interesting thought exercise, but I think the video doesn't consider enough that technology introduces possible extinction events. We already have created technologies which can destroy us, such as nuclear weapons, and we will likely invent others in the near future. Even if the risk of such an apocalypse occurring in any given year is less than 1% for each apocalyptic scenario, over a 1,000 or 10,000 years the odds start to become increasingly likely. Unless something changes and we do more to eliminate those risks, it eventually becomes inevitable.

This is why it is extremely important that we become a multiplanetary species to mitigate this risk. Personally speaking, I think the most likely outcome is that we end up creating our own successors; once strong AI takes off it will probably not be long before it is the dominant species on the planet. Organic humans will become out-competed and become extinct, or more optimistically, replaced by a synthetic intelligence that we directed ourselves to evolve into.

Great video as always, but this one misses another crucial, far more likely scenario IMO, so please hear me out while I try to break it down:

- Humans are on the brink of pausing/stopping ageing altogether (Kurzgesagt has a video on this!), we already had some success with mice, so the possibility to have every human being live forever is within reach, certainly in the next 100-200 years.

- We are becoming really really good in tricking our brains that stuff is real when it's really not, think Virtual Reality. Just think about how computer graphics looked around 30 years ago and what they look like now and now think ahead 100 years and you probably will have systems that will simulate EVERY possible stimulus (visual, aural, haptic sensations, everything) you can think of and probably even more.

Now combine these two developments and you get a future that probably looks like this:
Every human being is living in either a shared or his/her very own reality with their body connected to systems that keep you alive while you're living a totally different, virtual life.

Think about it, why would we as human beings strive to advance ourselves to build rockets and spaceships to explore other endlessly floating rocks in space that are just like ours, to what purpose?

Why would we make new human beings in the real world, when we can "play through" a whole lifetime of growing up, having jobs and a family and eventually die (probably all in a matter of minutes in the real-world), all in a simulation that's being directly delivered to our brains. Why would we continue to build cities, infrastructure (apart from the necessary ones to keep this thing going), why would we go to war with each other anymore, to what purpose?

What would we strive for in the "real world" when we can have it all, only more beautiful, fulfilling and intense inside our brain without moving a muscle.
Our current reality will become a meaningless phenomenon compared to all the sensations you can/will have in the other "virtual" realities.

Well thinking this through, maybe we are already living in such a simulation, which would tie into another Kurzgesagt video, so let's just end the thought experiment here. :)

PS: Back to the initial question of the video - yes, there will probably be a "last" human being born, because probably we will collectively decide to not bring anymore humans to this real world and do the "big switch" or something like that. So there's that? :D

9:40

I know we agreed on this analysis containing many assumptions, which makes sense, and I accept that. This is a great video developed through creativity and assumptions, but with rational lines of thought.
The one thing I must question is @4:30 using the assumption of a constant birth rate year over year instead of a variable birthrate creates unnecessary inaccuracies. (.) If we assume the population increases over time and the ratio of births per human remains constant, then it is logical that the yearly birth rate would increase over time. More humans able to reproduce = more baby humans. The key point in this paragraph is to distinguish between the definitions of birth rate (total humans born in a year) vs. birth ratio per human (average number of humans 1 human creates).

For example, (totally made up numbers) - if every 1 human born create a worldwide average of 1.1 humans, then during a year with a world population of 10B humans, the population would increase by 1B humans (10Bx1.1=11B). Assuming the same ratio of births per human, during a year with a world population of 100B humans, the population would increase by 10B humans (100Bx1.1=110B).

The entire point of this comment (besides selfishly making me feel better and not freaking out about maths) is to point out that @4:33 the stated number of humans waiting to be born,100 trillion, is much lower that it would be because the model creates a linear line of growth when graphed. The model using a variable birth rate would create an exponential line of growth if graphed, which means the statement referencing 100 trillion humans waiting to be born is an underestimate. This results in the next statement regarding there being 850 times greater number of humans waiting to be bornd than the number of humans that have already been born to be underestimated. Finally, the underestimation above results in the next statement @4:40 estimating the number of the current human population is only 0.008% of all people who will ever live lower.

In conclusion, the change to the model from linear population growth to exponential population growth increases the magnitude of your argument about putting us at the beginning of something big instead of the end. The change to the model increases future population estimates throughout the remainder of the video, which again enhances he magnitude of your conclusions.

I have to disagree with the first part of the video. Humans likely will not hit 11B of population by 2100. If you look at the data gathered in the past decades, fertility rates are declining at a scary rate. In mens alone, fertility is declining by almost 1% every year, mainly due to poor air quality and processed food. On top of that, sits the facts that more and more people choose to have less kids or not at all, this goes hand to hand with the progression of the living standard.
Taking these factors into account, in the next 50 years our population will look like 35% elders, 45% adults and 15% children.
So, by 2100 most likely our population growth will collapse, calculated with current data to 2B people.
Hope this scenario doesn't happen, because I am also a fan of " the more people living a good life = more opportunities to invent and to improve our life" , but numbers are numbers, and we should not neglected this data.

One of the biggest issues with increased numbers of Humans that doesn’t get mentioned in thought experiments like this is, how that will mean less natural world for the already threatened life on this planet.

More people with a high quality of life means less for the rest of life on this planet... which ultimately will result in our undoing as life is a big complex interconnected thing on this planet.

Also worth pointing out that the industrial revolution resulted in a huge increase in numbers, only to get more people working in those factories.

Now we are in the digital age, we don't need to be as numerous as we are. Less people means that we can have a fantastic quality of life, while also allowing the rest of life on this planet the space and respect that it should have.

What a great day for another existential crisis brought to you by Kurzgesagt...

I adore this message. And I believe messages of this nature invite us to consider the leverage we as individuals have.

Why do negative, destructive perspectives gain momentum and dominate the collective consciousness? Because the persistent, charismatic, persuasive, and powerful give them life. Because the listeners and digesters, the hurt and hopeless, give them momentum. Because the great mechanisms that drive communication and understanding in our society are held and honed by the persistent, charismatic, persuasive, and powerful.

None of this is inevitable. Like advanced energy-storage technologies and rocket ships, our systems of media, communication, interaction, and connection are inventions someone brilliant built, and that we, as societies, have invested in. Every destructive system, even geopolitical meshes of radical, cultural, and spiritual complexity, was invented and invested in.


There IS a way to disentangle these. Some discoveries in science have taken centuries to unravel, and the process of unraveling is still occurring. In the same vein, there is no human system, possibly no physical system, that cannot be corrected (or optimized) given enough focus and creative energy.

When we allow our hurt to shut us down; when we abandon hope, we lose our greatest assets as humans - creativity and focus. These are the only scenarios in which the world's problems cannot be fixed. If we take proper care of ourselves, learning how to adeptly and lovingly navigate the emotionally charged tangle within, we can dedicate our lives to overcoming any conceivable challenge.

I believe this is the core of what drives Kurzgesagt, or at least how I interpret it. And it is best given voice in this video. This is what a radical, uninhibited investment in our creative potential yields. I love your passion and hope your perspective flies free for years to come.

After being passed unanimously in the Senate on May 6, S-204 was introduced by Garnett Genuis, Member of Parliament (MP), in the House of Commons on May 10.

Similar legislation has been introduced by Canadian MPs previously. This includes MP Borys Wrzesnewskyj (2008), MP Irwin Cotler (2013), Salma Ataullahjan (2017), and Garnett Genuis (2017). Those bills were also supported by MPs from across all parties, but they were not able to get through the entire process to become law.

David Matas said 15 years have passed since he and Kilgour published their first investigative report on organ harvesting in 2006. It has also been 13 years since such a bill was first introduced in 2008. He said no one in this parliament session opposes this bill. Dai also said MPs in her area had said that S-204 is supported by all members of parliament. It is critical that the Canadian Parliament pass Bill S-204 as soon as possible.

Over One Million Signatures Against Forced Organ Harvesting
Doctors Against Forced Organ Harvesting (DAFOH) started a global petition in 2013 to oppose the forced organ harvesting in China. Within 5 months, over 1.5 million signatures were collected in more than 50 nations. They were submitted to the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR), urging immediate action to stop the forced organ harvesting of Falun Gong practitioners in China.

In an announcement on June 14, the United Nations Human Rights Council stated that the accusations against the CCP for harvesting organs from detained Falun Gong practitioners, Uyghurs, Tibetans, Muslims, and Christians are shocking.

These days, folks feel compelled to be cynical about where things are headed and there are many things that happen on a regular basis which give us fodder for focusing on the negative. And many long term positive trends go unreported. I think part of the compulsion to signal cynicism comes from overindexing on humilty. Humility is a key ingredient in driving science forward as we need to start with uncertainty across almost all propositions in order to open us up to investigating those propositions and thus generating knowledge. But, myths such as the Tree of Knowledge, Pandora's Box, and Promethian Fire reflect a sense we have that the slightest overreach will close the door to a good future. To the contrary, problems are soluable. Solutions do lead to new problems, so this is a treadmill we cannot escape. But, problems are soluable, solutions do constitute progress, and the alternative is death, so I will take the treadmill.

And, with all that as background, I return to topic of the video. It is true that our descendents are counting on us (in some sort of outside-of-the-universe, time-independent view). An optimistic belief that a good life for them is possiple should be factored into our calculus much more than it currently is. I believe that a failure to be compelled by a positive vision for the future does hamper our ability to create the solutions that will enable something resembling that future.

No, it won't. It won't happen that way. As we (hopefully) spread out into the cosmos, we will continue to evolve as we're exposed to different environments and challenges to life -- to a point where our current concept of humanity will gradually slip away and be replaced by something else entirely (maybe better, maybe worse). This change will be both biological and sociological and will take millions of years -- as it always has. We humans like to get hung up on our "humanhood" quite a bit. Oblivious to the fact that we're merely a blip in the overall course of biological imperative. Life has other plans. And as it spreads, it will take on forms with a purpose that we can't possibly imagine.

Kurtz was extremely conservative because he didn't factor in human mating behaviors. If that many people did exist, it's likely that their ancestors would be composed of a minuscule number of Y chromosomes. In other words, there would be very little male genetic variation. If we extrapolate from history, we find that not many men got to sire offspring. It was probably when the agricultural neolithic era and founding of religion saw the largest number of males able to sire offspring. Without the need for religious practices, human mating behaviors fall into tournament mating strategies. There is a book called "Dating Up: The Hypergamy Factor" which speaks on this. Therefore the genetic variation among the species is limited and that puts humanity at risk for diseases that attack the Gene's and/or birth defects. This video is extremely optimistic and conservative. It also seems that Kurtz hasn't been keeping up with the political and "technosocial" trends. Increases in technology have isolated humans more rather than bring them together.

If you want to think on how long humans can survive, you should first define what a human is. I mean mankind, as we know it, is definitely doomed. If we don't kill ourselves, we will inevitably be able to change our body and our mind. Consider a being, one of our late descendants, who can easily survive without air in an environment with (currently) deadly radiation and who is so intelligent that compared to him, we are less than apes. Is that still a human? If not, there will be a transition and there will be no strict border between humans and "posthumans".
This is something like the "first human". If you could go back in time, would you be able to point at one single first human? And his/her mother was necessarily not a human. Of course, this was a continuous transition with no strict border. In a very similar way, there will probably be no "last human".

To anyone that hasn't read Isaac Asimov's "Foundation/Empire" series, stop putting off a great read. Audiobooks if you dont' like to read.

In that series, taking place 20,000+ years in the future (this was written LONG before warhammer, star wars, etc), humanity has spread across the galaxy, in some case becoming isolated and evolving on their own worlds, and have all long forgotten Earth. Most people in that universe/lore think that Earth is a silly myth and that humans surely just arose naturally via evolution on multiple worlds. The conclusion to the series is pretty bleak IMO when they do end up finding earth, well worth the read. I'm fairly sure most sci-fi today is based off the Empire/Robot series written by Asimov back in the 50's.

While it would be nice to think it'll all be fine and this is just the beginning this video does make major assumptions. You're assuming that technology and human innovation has no limit and can solve every problem, I would argue humans definitely have intellectual limits though how far we're off them is unknown of course. So far we've solved all our problems via mining our planet of resources which are rapidly running out (fuels, fertilisers, minerals etc). Sure technology may get better for recycling a lot of these resources but recycling still costs energy/water/pollution at a higher rate than simple mining (eg wind power costs more resources/pollution to make than it can ever offset.), so where is this energy going to come from?
So far it's come from our depleting resources. Yes there's other options but it so far been diminishing returns across the board. Innovation requires room to waste and fail, we won't be able to keep innovating if we don't have enough resources.
Kurzgesagt has already covered other issues that would be major issues, eg leaving the planet won't be an option if space junk traps us here, that's assuming we even have enough energy to leave the planet anymore.
Sorry but for me this video was a bit too feel-goody and glossing over the big issues we're already facing (I get why, I'm just saying I need more convincing to lose the pessimistic outlook).

Guesstimating lifespan of humans as species is incredibly speculative. On the one hand, a certain country might start nuclear war and wipe us all out tomorrow. On the other hand, if we assume we'll manage to avoid become reason for our own downfall... There's no way of predicting how long we'll last. Every species that had gone extinct in the previous eons done so because they couldn't adapt to the changing environments fast enough genetically. Humans, due to their intelligence, live on a completely different time scale than most species. A drastic change of environment in the span of 1000 years will be nigh instantaneous in terms of evolution and will leave any species little chance to adapt to it. For humans, though, the change will be creeping upon us so slowly we would be barely aware of its progress, with plenty of time to think, plan, and devise ways to cope with it. So this means truly global extinction events like GRBs, but those are black swans - they cannot be predicted.
So in the end, humans will as likely to either die out tomorrow, or survive for billions of years until the sun will explode (and probably beyond that even).

Unfortunately, the science is not on our side for an expanding population and progress. The 30-year update to The Limits to Growth puts us right on track for civilizational collapse somewhere around mid-century (that's this one). The galaxy has tons of energy, but most of it is neither accessible nor usable to humans, nor will it ever be. Our civilization is wholly reliant upon fossil fuels to mine, refine, process, assemble, and distribute goods and services. Once we run out, every civilized human thing becomes harder to do. No evidence has yet been presented to the contrary.

The last human to be born may not be born this century, but humanity is about to fall from an unimaginable height. Nature always gets the last word.

Hey all future people

Maybe I'm missing something, but most of this video seems to rest on a seriously flawed assumption.

It mentions one aspect early on: "It's pretty unlikely that birth rates will stay stable forever". But birth rate is just the start - the video assumes that if our descendants survive millions of years or even longer, they will continue to resemble "people" in even a very broad sense. For example: existing as large numbers of clearly distinguishable minds per small region of space (say, per planetary body); maintaining those per-region numbers at population levels at least similar to today, if not many orders of magnitude larger; continuing to reproduce at all, and at similar rates... the birth rate consideration is almost a footnote.

Around halfway through, the video mentions one possible reason for humanity to do this: "more humans may actually mean more progress". But if technological society survives the coming centuries, then I can't see how our problem-solving capacity would have anything to do with the size of the human population. Again, maybe I'm missing something - but it seems to me that in such a technological far future, the vast majority of problem-solving would surely involve technology. Whether we think of that as mere software, artificial intelligence, cybernetic enhancements, or whatever else is almost beside the point: I just can't see most of that decision-making plausibly consisting of human beings thinking human thoughts.

Now, you could argue that even as we continue to develop technology to make decisions for us, those decisions will still be "guided" by ordinary people making decisions of our own (e.g. providing the technology with feedback, or designing new forms of it), and that the number of people guiding this process is what will really determine the rate of progress in science, technology or problem-solving in general. And sure, that's true now and for the immediately foreseeable future. But I really can't imagine how any technological society could exist for millions of years - if not far longer - and still have its problem-solving capacity limited in any way by the number of ordinary people.

I'm interested to hear if anyone has thoughts about this.

I’ve been fighting an uphill battle trying to convince people close to me that the future can not only be better, but unimaginably better, and that there is a scenario where humanity lives for trillions of years to come. Some key people in my family are unimaginably pessimistic about our ability to keep going, and they think the world is going down the drain. I think this is largely due to that perspective being popular and in vogue right now. The political climate makes it seem like nobody can agree on anything and that the out group is so incompetent that the only explanation for their actions is malady against society in general. That is obviously false, and I can say that with confidence because everyone thinks that about everyone else, but not themselves. Deep down the vast majority of people are trying to do the right thing. Even if we get that wrong and there are bad actors in play, that should give us some hope. All of us want everything to be okay. I think religion does play a role too. Like the video states, everyone thinks the world is ending when their alive and then life just keeps going. This is ESPECIALLY true of Advent Christian religions by which I mean Christian denominations that believe Jesus is coming to save us by destroying the old earth and creating a new one. They infer that because this is the case, any human attempt to make things better is futile, and the only way everything will work out is if Jesus destroys this earth and purges humanity of sin which will be done with fire and brimstone. In fact, many of us celebrate the end times because it means we are closer to the end of human suffering. My family and I are Seventh Day Adventists and we all share this eschatology. I’ve noticed it used as a coping mechanism. Many of our discussions about the happenings of the world end with us saying that whatever terrible event  that just happened is fine because Jesus will come and fix everything in the end. It allows us to keep going when all seems lost. However, a side-effect is that we are very pessimistic and if we really took our religion seriously, we would be utterly uninterested in the future, and we wouldn’t try to make anything “better” or fix anything or address any problems. Luckily, we still care about things like that, but the video is right, it makes us very myopic in approaching large-scale problems. To be fair, we obviously aren’t the only ones who suffer from “existential myopia” if you will. It’s obviously just one manifestation of a psychological truth buried deep in human consciousness, we know we won’t last forever, and we’re afraid of that both individually and collectively. We all have to figure out how to respond to that and it’s no trivial task. My point is that regardless of how you respond, there is a possible potential universe where humanity thrives and solves one problem after another until there are only trivial problems that are easily handled. And while there is also a possible potential universe that is the opposite of that and everything in between, it makes sense to have faith that if we all devote our lives to trying to make things better or at least less bad, then that amazing future is far more likely to happen. It’s okay to be skeptical, but we can’t be cynical. It’s okay to think that God will solve everything in the end, but we can’t let that keep us from following Him in the meantime. This world does matter and people are counting on us. Even if the end is near, there’s no way to know that. It’s our responsibility to assume it isn’t and plan for a better future. One as far away from hell as possible.

Before we can develop further, we need to contract first. Our dependence on fossil fuels gave us those 8,000 million humans alive today, but that dependence is now at an end. If we cannot re-engineer our entire civilization to support 8,000 million without fossil fuel inputs, then we are going to suffer a massive die-off. That's just simple physics. The last time we lived on Earth without constant fossil fuel inputs (about the year 1700) we were around 400 million people, mostly employed in agriculture, with very few elites. 400 million is 5% of the current population. I don't see how we avoid seeing that same number again. Any real chance of averting a massive die-off is rapidly slipping away, and in fact, might already be behind us. It now falls to everyone alive to try and refactor how they live in order to survive without ANY fossil fuel inputs and do that before 2025. Those who can manage that change may inherit the future and can start civilization again on a radically altered planet Earth.

another point I think is important to emphasize that I feel this video (as good as it is on the topics it does cover) did a fairly poor job of is the difference between the end of humanity, and the end of our current civilization. far too often. scenarios that, in reality. would only kill off complex civilization. are treated as extinction level events. for example. take global nuclear war. a global nuclear war would wipe out human civilization as we know it. but unless you plan on literally carpet nuking the entire surface. it wouldn't knock out humans. people in the amazon rain forest might not even notice.
I think its important to remember that we are not our cities. we are not our technology nor are we our organizations. we are humans. we are individual animals all capable of surviving on our own should the need arise again. give the world a few millennia. and even a devastating nuclear war or asteroid strike that knocked out 99% of us would hardly be noticeable. our numbers fell below 10 000 at one point, we still recovered. human civilization would rise again. perhaps even faster then it did the first time around depending on how much tech is lost. and we'd be back on our way towards the stars.
perhaps in the future, you could emphasize this point further. a hurdle. like nuclear war, climate change, or super volcano, is just that, a hurdle. a setback. a delay. not an end.

It's great to see all this optimism in the comments, but it's a little too much in my opinion.

Sure, as of today it would take a literal disaster to end our entire race with all the measures such as shelters, seed vaults and whatnot. However, looking at history, it seems that eras of renewed prosperity are almost always ushered by unprecedented suffering (eg. transition from nomad to sedentary, dark ages before renaissance, WWII before the Trente Glorieuses), and the cycles are becoming shorter and more intense as technology advances.
This is why I find it laughably naïve to think that your own personal future will be secured simply based on big picture predictions.
Yes, the upcoming series of crisis will probably appear as mere bumps on the road for an outsider observing the human race, but actually living the reality of the upcoming climate changes and energetic transition (or rather energetic shock), well..

Let's just say there won't be much room for daydreaming of futuristic utopias

I often get existential discomfort thinking about just how deep the well of time is, both past and future. This was such a beautiful change of perspective, to think about all the incredible things that may yet come to be if we're careful. I deeply hope that we find life-extension techniques soon, I just want to see it all so badly

Can you imagine what would happen if most people watching this decide to go out and make a difference in the world? That's what we should do - we should take this as inspiration and go do incredible things, things that would lay the foundation for the future to be built on. We can all help, if we believe, and if we try really really hard.

Let's go! We got this!!!

Yes, truly there is so much potential if people could just view things in cosmological timescales and distances, realizing both how insignificant we truly are in the grand scheme and yet how much we can achieve in spite of that.

But then, that's exactly the problem. A lot of people these days can't seem to grasp that there's more to existence than them and their immediate surroundings, and a lot of these short- and narrowsighted people are in positions of power. That's why doomerism is so high- it's not because there's no potential for a brighter, more prosperous future, it's because we stand no chance of reaching that future if we as a species can't get our act together, and that looks like more and more of a futile prospect.

6:46 "grim and dark, as science fiction likes to paint it" Correction: most of the grim and dark future stories are closer to fantasy novels, especially outside of dedicated books, ie popular culture. It's very clearly spelled out in the name of the genre too: SCIENCE fiction. Not not FUTURE fiction, not DISTOPIA fiction, not CYBER fiction, not ALIEN fiction, not ROCKET fiction, not SPACE fiction, not TIMETRAVEL fiction, but SCIENCE fiction. The distinction is in the focus and driving force of the story. If you can change out the setting and it still is a coherent story, then most likely it's not science-fiction. If the story is driven by facts and logical extrapolations and conclusions, then it's probably science-fiction.
The importance of terminology should be clear to anyone valuing communication, and the failure of this distinction means finding Harry Potter movies in the Science-Fiction section, like you do on Amazon Prime Video.

This doesn't account for the fact that all developed nations are far below replacement level birth rates. Even most middle-income and even low-income countries are rapidly moving towards replacement or are at it (China, India, Indonesia, LatAm, MENA, and Asia in general are all at or below replacement, and even Africa outside the Sahel is moving rapidly towards it). I doubt we reach 11bn as this video suggests, more like ~9bn in the 2060s, with Africa peaking around 3-4bn. Unless we artificially raise birth rates through artificial wombs, I suspect the human population will dramatically shrink, potentially by more than half, in the coming centuries.

If we live in today's world, arguably we could say it's logical as it was the time where we were the most likely to be born, since there's a lot more people around ready to potentially create us in the industrial time. That would "explain" why we were born now and not earlier, even though a lot more time passed in the previous eras ; you're just more likely to be born when the number of humans is high. Following this idea, we could also say that if we're only 0.008% of the number of people that is supposed to be born in the next million year, then we were very unlikely to be born now "by coincidence". And so it'd feel more probable to be born later on "if" humanity would still last a million of years. If the number of humans suffer from a sharp decline in the coming decades / next century, though, then we could say we were just born around the time where we were the most likely to be born and we're not special.
This logic could've been applied by any of our ancestors, though, and we wouldn't be there if they let defeatism consumed them. So we should try to make sure we're just a statistical anomaly and tread lightly on the future humans' behalf.

FACT: Earth's resources (for organic life) are finite.
FACT: Earth's 'soil cycle' is breaking down (probably irreversibly).
FACT: Lakes are drying up at unprecedented rates. Fish are thin as F (Lake Mead is one gigantic example).
FACT: Plastics have penetrated absolutely every corner of the planet. These are nearly impossible to break down (even though tech has evolved to help).

So, assuming that humanity can even survive to 3200 (doubtful), it's not so much the OBVIOUS things as it will be the less obvious ones. For example, if all bees die, or all fish in nearly every lake perish.
