There is a flip side to this argument, though - which is the sheer improbability of actually being born at that beginning.

Let's say that 100 quadrillion humans will ever exist, a fair conservative number as explained by this video. In that case, the odds of being among the first 117 billion people ever born is about 1 in 10 million - extremely unlikely. And of course, that number will only become even more unlikely if we assume higher numbers of people in the future, like a sextillion or even a tredecillion humans. In that case, the odds will go from extremely unlikely to unfathomably unlikely.

I've heard a few possible explanations to this seeming paradox, but none of them seem particularly satisfy.

For one, we could just have made that insanely unlikely dice roll. After all, no matter how improbable, someone had to be in that super-early group, thinking about how unlikely their birth was.

Another, and probably the most unpleasant explanation, would be the doomsday argument - which basically states that the end of humanity really is closer than we think. If, say, only 300 billion people will ever be born, then being one of the first 117 billion becomes far more likely.

A third idea would be the simulation hypothesis. The basic summery would be that the "Star Trek future" already have been achieved, and we are living in a simulated version of earth as it was in the year 2022.
This would make some sense, since the current period - the period right before humans really started expanding into space, would likely be a time that future humans would want to experience. In the same vein as how we enjoy reading history and from the roman era or playing video games from the early 80s, just to try and understand what things used to be like in the past, people in the future would probably want to simulate our reality to understand what our lives used to be like.

What do you think?

Thanks for this video, changed my view completely on the perspective of time, something that I think will be important to keep in mind however is the concept of "we". The last human will be born (or grown) eventually but they will almost definitely not be the last living thing to be born.

At the moment, the main concept of "we" is humanity. This changes constantly though. Tens of thousands of years ago, "we" was your tribe, a few millennia ago and it was your culture. To Europeans a few centuries ago, it was Europe and their colonies. In the future, I theorise that "our" history will not be just human history but that of every sentient life form we encounter in the cosmos.

Today we regard "our" history as that of the history of every human and human culture, that wasn't the case 500 years ago. While human culture will still be focused on and discussed in the future, the concept and relative term for "us" or "we" in the use of history will most likely not be determined by human history, but of sentient history.

That's my opinion and theory of how future generations will see the past and its history.

Thank goodness we've got Kurzgesagt to put humanity's problems into perspective with its clown-shoe colors and cartoon chickens. It's actually such a human dose of "don't look at the tsunami out at sea rushing in, look at the pretty sand and your iPhone... we're clever aren't we!!" Conjuring up vast uncountable numbers of future humans is surely a game for those who think billionaires are gonna build cities for us on Mars, an outcome as likely as a team from Antarctica winning next year's Superbowl. Smarter folk than me have already told us with cold logic that IF there was gonna be a future where humans colonize other planets and/or expand out into the galaxy, that's most likely where we'd be living right NOW. Time is just a data-set. You're alive NOW reading these words NOW because this is the brief moment in history when there are more humans drawing breath than ever before... statistically, this is the most likely time for any randomly selected human life to happen. If there was going to be a golden future with countless trillions of us living all over the galaxy, it would be highly probable that you'd be reading this on some ancient data tape and laughing at the foolishness of your ancestors. But hey, don't worry, the cartoon cavemen are dreaming big, and Kurzgesagt will keep on entertaining you with glib smarts and colorful techno-porn.😏

I hope that one-day Kurzgesagt would touch on gun control. My best mate and I had a very passionate discussion about it recently.
He believes everyone should have the right to hold a weapon for sake of self-defense, claiming that if there was drama between someone who's armed and someone who's not, that drama would have come and gone before the authorities arrived. And that those who want to own illegal weapons will get their hands on them, regardless of the law.
If everyone owned weapons, those looking to do harm will think twice before doing so.
Some good arguments, I'd admit.
My argument was that not all of us have a need to hold weapons. That what we hear on the news is not our reality. That these rare occurrences don't happen to the majority of us, as long as we don't encourage these behaviors by giving these criminals a spotlight or "walking down that dark alley" ourselves. I believe owning guns and weapons will only raise casualties, not lower them. Live by the sword, die by the sword. 
We're both Australians by the way. Most of us don't own guns. Those who own rifles, use them for hunting or sport. Not counting criminals who own whatever they like from the black market. 
And we both agree that things will go wrong either way and that no system is perfect. 
I ask you, are we safer for not owning our own self-defense? What was it like in the past? What are some good examples of countries on both sides of the argument? What would the future look like? 
It would be nice to see Kurzgesagt video on this like their Vaccines video.
P.S, please keep the comments civil. I don't intend on sparking a flame war. Respect each other.

The Mediocrity Principle is necessary to consider, here.  If there are millions or billions or more of years of people being born, and quadrillions or octillions or more total people, what are the odds that you-- the person reading this-- were born almost right at the very beginning?  There will always be more room in the middle somewhere than at either end,, and the larger and longer the middle area is, the more likely you are to be occupying some area in it.  There's always one beginning, and one end, but the middle is variable.

From the linked article, "The average mammalian species lasts for about one million years. Homo sapiens have been around for only 200,000" - but other mammalian species have sustainable resource consumption based on their environments (except for when we manipulate their environment, like removing apex predators or the Reindeer of St. Matthew Island). Humans are unique in the sense that per capita our resource consumption is orders of magnitude higher than other mammals, and in the last few hundred years we've made the comparison to other species' longevity almost moot - and while I love the idea of Longtermism, we have to overcome our desire for extremely wasteful consumption habits. Foods that require a tremendous amount of water would be a good start.

As a science communicator with experience translating a few scientific papers and publications into Japanese, I'm extremely happy about the language expansion! Most people don't realize how very little gets translated and used in different parts of the world with drastically different cultures from the West (and sometimes vice versa). Studies involving socially sensitive topics are hard to translate to different cultures, let alone publish with credibility in places that do not see certain ideas or scientific concepts the same way (especially with the social sciences or with some socially constructed concepts in the hard sciences, like taxonomies and disease classification). We do have people who carry science with their profession across the world themselves, but only so many people can do that with the speed at which new science evolves and updates itself. I might be a teensy bit biased, but I strongly feel we need more sharing of science across language and cultural barriers, and more demand for such cross-cultural expansion of science in general! Love your work~ <3

The problem is we live in a world that selects for those who make decisions which help themselves and their corporations, not for helping others - those who have yet to be born. The only thing that matters for being successful in this world is the bottom line, what will get you the best return on investment. There are people who focus on helping others and who pursue objectives which do not have monetary reward, but in a system where success is measured in profit, they will not earn a platform for their ideas to be spread. We need a world which is incentivized to be giving, and pursue a life that isn’t focused on money. As technology exponentially increases and service jobs begin to be more efficiently performed by technology, we will need more focus on allowing people to pursue passions such as arts, music, painters, sports, writers, etc. The way the world works now, most people cannot pursue these passions because they do not provide enough money. If we want to make a change, we need a world where money is not the only factor to be considered. With the power of technology, we are coming to a point where such a major shift has the ability to occur. To survive the Great Filter of greed, we need to make this change.

The phrase “take it with a grain of salt” is sarcasm. It originates from recipes for potions, cure alls, and other pseudo science concoctions that often had a single grain of salt in the recipe.

The single grain of salt isn’t going to have any substantial effect, because it’s small.

So “take that with a gigantic grain of salt” actually means the opposite of “take that with a grain of salt.” However “take that with the smallest grain of salt.” Would be a more extreme version of “take that with a grain if salt.”

This video makes me feel worse. Why?
To look at the existence of potential people in the future as of some inherent worth and relevance to ourselves (other than to have a less depressed perspective on the future), makes me think, that people shift the attention to actual existing people in the very present. It does not make any difference for us now other than being optimistic and proud about your own kind, which is arbitrary anyway, and even worse, if you think of your own kind exclusive to others (see relgion, race, nation or other concepts). Don't care about the Sextillioin potentials, but care about the 8 billion other humans dwelling on this rock with youat this very moment. You personally don't get to know either of them ever.

Thus, what would be an important focus of our actions and thoughts, though, is not to aim for the sheer existence of potential people in the (distant or not so distant) future, but to focus on the very existing people now, from the newborn to the oldest, and to do as much as possible to achieve the best for them (which basically is all of us) in our lifetime. There are enough individuals alive right now, who would be still alive in the 22nd century.
Let's better aim our actions to make it a liveable and liveworthy future. Everyone not being born nor conceived yet, is - to be honest - irrelevant.

And this is, what bothers me most about this kurzgesagt video, although i highly appreciate the work and effort: It is close to a strong but illogical religious belief, that people would be waiting in heavens happily awaiting to be born. As for most of the kurzgesagt videos, I am glad that religious believes don't matter for their content nor their message. Alas, apparently this sort of religious thinking plays a major role in this one.

There is about a 1% chance that humans will die off if not less. There however is a greater likelihood that either a natural disaster (major volcano, meteor strike, pandemic) or human made (nuclear war fall out or some advance weapon we don't have yet) will drastically lower our population.

We at this point are point are beyond being wiped out for the most part for the following reasons:

1) Under ground bunkers for the ultra rich and those lucky to be selected to join them and they will take computers and other technology with them. Indeed, I'm sure there is already computers and tech in said bunkers protected from pretty much EVERYTHING.
2) Technology in it's various forms
3) The sheer fact that there are 8bilion of us.

We have the tech to quickly make many more under ground bunkers. These bunkers would give us time to bring technology we already have into production level to start making more space stations OR even clean up any disaster on the planet.

Seriously, think about it. Say there is a major meteor strike that wipes out 90% of the population in a week. That's enough time for the 10% that is left to get into under ground shelter. There for sure are plans to get scientists of all types to safety imminently at the sign of a potential major disaster OR imminently after. Same goes for tech they will need in the future: Planes, computers etc etc etc. Same goes for the fall out or whatever from a war.

10% of 8billion is 800 MILLION people left on the planet, that is MORE then enough for us to survive and not even lose any modern day technology if they are prepared in advance. And you can very well bet there ARE plans in place.

And those that are worried about solar flares destroying humanity due to the power grid and any active machine/device that is turned don being wiped out. That will only set us back for 50 years at MOST until another power grid and new machines come online to replaces those that burned out. However, I bet it won't be pretty and there will be mass die offs of us.

We're pretty much past the point of a complete extinction.

What should worry you all more is just what a billion is when it comes to dollars and that there are people on this planet "worth" 4billion or more. That they all have gotten that way by exploiting the planet and others for their benefit.

I normally like your videos, but this seems to be just such a shortsighted extrapolation.
First, we are so much further in genetic engineering than we are on the road to creating self-sustainable civilizations on other planets in the solar system, that it is not even a question what will come first. (in your video, you indicate the reverse)
Second, what makes you think we advance that much in science, but still will keep our 20ish generational cycle forever?
Before we find ways to colonize the galaxy, we will probably find ways to cheat death through "aging". And then reproduction will get an even larger sociological problem. No matter how and if we will continue making children forever, it will probably not be such that we can make reliable predictions, just dependent on the time scales and available resources.

I don't want to be a negative thinker. But let's for a moment calculate the chance of you being born in those different scenario's.
Scenario 1 (don't leave earth): the chance of living amongst the 'first' 117 billion people will be:
((117x10^9)/(100x10^12))*100= 0.117 %
(already a very small percentage but still possible)

Scenario 2 (leaving earth): the chance of living amongst the first 117 billion people will be:
((117x10^9)/(10x10^21))x100 = 0.00000000117 %
This number is already way smaller than you winning the lottery with 100million(!) people playing. Still possible but 'rather' unlikely.

Scenario 3 (leaving solar system): the chance of living amongst the first 117 billion people will be:
((117*10^9)/(100*10^27))*100= 0.000000000000000117%
This number is so unfathomably small that you are more likely to win TWO of those lotteries (with 100million players) IN A ROW. Which is an astronomically small chance.

Scenario 4 (Largest guesstimate from kurzgesagt): the chance of living amongst the first 117 billion people will be:
((117*10^9)/(4*10^42))*100 = 0.000000000000000000000000000002925 %
This number is SO small, that it is a MILLION times more likely to win THREE lotteries with 100million players IN A ROW. Which is so small that it would be literally impossible for any human on earth to do.

Conclusion:
If we use those percentages you can argue that the chance of humans ever leaving the earth are so small (otherwise you would be way more likely to be born in those generations) that we will probably never leave the earth and we might already be one of the last living humans on earth.

(TL;DR. It is wayyy more likely for us to be born in the 'end of times' than it is for us to be born at the absolute beginning of the total human time.)

This assumes humans continue to become more intelligent or remain as intelligent as we are now. But intelligence is not the end goal of evolution. Evolution has no end goal. Intelligence has severed us well so far, but most species clearly don't need it. Other traits have served them just as well.
Intelligence is extremely expensive, and the advantage it gives us has to outweigh the cost.
If, over several generations intelligence is not needed as much, it will decline in the population. If that population is isolated, then a new species will split off from us, one that is less intelligent and more animal like.
We may already be seeing this. Currently there is a large correlation between a person's success and the number of children they have. The more highly educated a person is, the more likely they are to delay or even forgo having children.
While there are exceptions everywhere the more education a person has the more intelligent they tend to be. We have a situation where the dumbest, most animal like humans are greatly out breeding the more intelligent people.

Scientists already estimate a 5% chance of extinction from global warming alone... given how peer review works it is probably a conservative estimate. Faster than light travel not being possible rules out most of your scenarios, and the lack of habitable atmosphere/etc. means space colonization is a huge waste of resources and energy. Recent studies suggest Mars, even with terraforming technology that does not and may never exist, might not be capable of building an atmosphere that is livable.

All of this science fantasy is irrelevant when you consider (unless we discover fusion ASAP) that we are past peak EROEI of oil and heading for a lower energy economy, possibly permanently. Or we just dig it all up and burn it, making that 5% much more like 50%... The idea that we can innovate our way out of the present predicament with technology instead of fixing our political-economic system, which is what actually needs to be done, is part of the problem.

I am a resident of Shandong Province and I have been practicing Falun Gong since 1996.

During the massive suppression against Falun Gong in China, many practitioners have been abused including forced organ harvesting. Master Li (founder of Falun Gong) said, “Live organ harvesting has been commonplace in many hospitals across China. It was a directive straight from the evil.” (“Fa Teaching Given at the New York Fa Conference Celebrating the 25th Anniversary of Dafa’s Spreading”)

Here I would like to share an incident that I encountered four years ago that shows forced organ harvesting does exist.

A Secret
At that time I lived in a community of Jinan City, Shandong Province. One day, I saw an old man in his 60s outside my apartment building. He looked skinny and pale, like a retired government official. When I saw him, he was checking a dumpster to see if he could get some cardboard.

I greeted him and we began to talk. He was indeed a retired government official. Coming from another city, he stayed at his son’s place. He seemed to be a nice person.

“I was released from hospital recently and I am bored staying inside,” he said. So he thought he would pick up some cardboard and sell it.

“But people who live in this community are wealthy in general. Is your son okay?” I asked.

“Because of my surgery, he has spent lots of money,” the man replied.

“You are a retired government official. Aren't your medical expenses covered by insurance?” I was surprised and asked.

“Not everything. For the operation I received, only part of it could be reimbursed,” he explained.

“Why not? Which hospital did you go to?” I asked.

“Qianfoshan Hospital and it was a heart transplant. My son spent over 400,000 yuan on it. This cannot be reimbursed,” he continued.

“I heard heart transplant is pretty easy nowadays. I knew several years ago people had to wait a long time because of the difficulty finding a matching organ,” I said.

“Ugh! Society is too dark now. There are clearly labeled price tags for all kinds of organs. It's all shameful deeds!” He sighed.

“Have you heard about live organ harvesting? Like those from Falun Gong practitioners?” I asked.

He was nervous. After looking around and making sure no one else was around, he lowered his voice and said, “It’s a secret. Those people [from the hospital] told my son to never tell anything about this.” Then his tears started to fall.
“Had I known this earlier, I would not have had such a sinful operation even if I had to die!” He cried out.

At that moment, I was almost certain this man’s organ was from a Falun Gong practitioner. Also in tears, I held his hands and said, “I know you are a kind person...” We cried together.

Continuing on that topic, I told him what Falun Gong is and how the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) had harmed Chinese people during numerous political campaigns. I also talked about organ harvesting from Falun Gong practitioners in many hospitals.

“I already knew the Party was no good, but did not know it’s so evil. It is horrible!” he said. He then quit all CCP organizations.

While this is nice and optimistic, this future won’t exist, as long as we worry and feel insecure. As long as we don’t trust each other, this won’t happen. And we don’t trust people because we don’t feel safe. A world like what was described can only exist if EVERYONE believes in it, works towards it, and not a single person is selfish or uncertain.

These predictions are far too optimistic, particularly cases 2 and 3.
If people exist, conflict will always follow. Things like galactic wars, spaceships, vicious planet killer plagues and planetary destroyers will likely come into being.
And then maybe after long and painful wars, would any sort of "law" be established.
If we look at things purely from the "how many lives are born" POV, then sure, many of us may come to exist. Despite that, the low lifespan of a human, added with the short term benefits oriented thinking, the end result is not pretty.

Many of you may find this perspective unlikely or maybe too pessimistic, but as it is only speculation, and is impossible to prove, it cannot be discarded as an option.

I think that humans of the future will be far less expansionistic and far more ecologistic. Sure, we COULD populate just about any star system up into the quadrillions of people, but why would we do it? We expand into every space available on Earth because it's easy and we aren't forced to think about it for it to happen. Thus, our instincts override our intellect, and all available habitable space gets used. But when we build habitation units in space or on uninhabitable worlds, it will be difficult and tedious. We will be forced to use our intellect to expand. We will not do it via instinct, but we will have to decide that it is actually important to do so. In many cases, more people can provide more opportunities for taking advantage of available resources. More people can operate mining facilities, more people can be scientists and engineers, more people can develop, design, and operate more equipment which can do great things. But we will want more people to achieve milestones of human civilization development. We will want more people to build stable interplanetary societies, to build colony ships, to secure valuable resources, to miniaturize high-end technology such as fusion reactors or interstellar spacecraft drives. Once we begin to achieve the top of our potential, and our focus on improving quality of life for everyone reaches the point where we can make people happy for life easily, then we will stop advancing and simply maintain. Some people may explore, but nobody will build a habitat simply because a rock exists to support it. Nobody will build an O'Neill Cylinder just because they have steel available. Nobody will colonize a planet just because it's a source of materials for expansion. Every bit of expansion will need a reason to happen. I see no reason to think humans won't expand to live across this galaxy and others, but we may have a population merely in the trillions or less.

The "people" distinction is a really powerful point in many respects. For most exoplanets that we know about, it would take long enough to get there and return with the best technology we currently can conceive of that whoever returned would not be the same species as the people on Earth that they returned to. Even the closest (Proxima Centauri) is estimated to be a 6300 year journey each way, and that's longer than humans have evidence of written language. By the time the first expedition got back, there is little chance they'll be understood by anyone they try to report to on what they saw.

Kurzgesagt videos always fill me with such wonder and sadness at the same time. Every one of them opens my eyes to an entire universe of new possibilities and outlooks on life. But at the same time I can't help but feel truly sad at how we humans keep squandering away our time and resources on pointless stuff.

We're so focused on our political views and killing each other that we get trapped in the now. What would the world look like if we focused on improving everything instead of destroying it? How far could we go in space if organizations had the proper funding and they collaborated globally? Just NASA alone said that with the proper funding - just a fraction of the defence budget - they could jump forward their timeline by over 50 years in a matter of years. Imagine if the whole world collaborated AND funded all the different organizations? We could have centuries of discoveries in our lifetimes! And that's just space exploration stuff, imagine if we worked together to stabilize food production and distribution so everyone in the world could eat delicious and healthy stuff without a million-dollar price tag. We could make such fun and cool things, discover so much and improve everyone's lives immeasurably. It'd be a relatively simple thing to end working altogether, leaving people to pursue what they want to do rather than whatever brings in money. If we focused on the clean production of energy and battery systems to store that energy we could automate everything necessary for modern living, completing everything we need for ALL of us to live good lives, without the need for limiting supply to those with money.

The entire world could change to become a place so much better and more interesting and fun than it is now - that's a real possibility not some fantasy - but it'll never happen because we're so busy killing each other or imposing our views on everyone. It's just sad to imagine where we'd be if people weren't so selfish, greedy, and blind.

We choose which delusions we want to follow. Some delusions can be healthy, with positive potential, while others, destructive. It could be the delusion of fame and fortune, or that science will fix everything for us, or that we need law and religion to be ethical, or that you are god incarnate. Which delusions cage your mind and which free it? We think we know what is real, but it's all human social construct. One thing I feel is real is that we are not merely visitors here, not only part of this reality, we are in fact the universe, experiencing itself as individuals. Everything that exists adding its unique conscious perspective. The elements of our bodies were forged in the stars, yet our consciousness is somehow not our body. And how awesome it is to get the human experience! Allowing us to share in great detail our individual perspectives and experiences, being able to imagine the infinite potential we, as life on earth, have yet to realize. I follow this delusion and I choose to believe we will collectively understand that we as humanity, are the ones that choose the quality of our world. The only thing holding us back is ourselves. We can choose to doubt ourselves or to believe in our limitless potential. Our reality seems to bend toward what we think and express. So I choose to imagine and speak of a utopian future, all living things in harmony and balance, learning from the intelligence of evolution to advance and create ideas and technology to make life more enjoyable for all of us equally, to protect life from existential threats. I would much rather be a nobody in that world than a winner of this competitive world. We choose.

Yes, 800 million more years is what scientists expect it to take for the sun to grow to such a size that life on landmasses on earth will become impossible (except for extremophiles possibly), so that is a reasonable time frame to choose. Hopefully we will stick to scenario 1 like all advanced alien civilizations we wouldn't know of existing, for the same reason. What is certain is that life will always be subjected to the all-powerful forces of the cosmos that are blind, unaware, uncaring of the consequences they come with, if they are catastrophic to life or good - they just happen. Though what is critical to not forget about all the speculative up-scaling of the potential amount of future people is how this up-scaling would in any case relate to the up-scaling of wildlife animal population sizes. Wildlife animals suffer more than farm animals in their perpetual demise of all 99.99...% of not-fittest, and this holds true in an especially grave manner for so-called r-selection strategist species, which mainly consist of the - relative to larger ones - very abundant smaller species that focus on maximizing their off-spring which necessitates minimized care on the individual level, leading to short excruciating lives for the vast majority of the off-spring in each generation (due to disease, injury, parasitism, starvation and malnutrition, dehydration, weather conditions, natural disasters, and killings by other animals), so if the latter case of farm animals' situation is discomforting enough already to think of, one should absolutely not forget the former. Ethics shouldn't just account for humans or people, but ethics requires a holistic, (with respect to sentient beings, astronomic time-spans, and living spaces) complete perspective. And doing so means to account for the fact that large multi-cellular life forms have existed on earth for billions of years, and not just for the previously estimated roughly 600 million years, which is by magnitudes far longer than humanity can realistically hope to stay on earth. For what eventually will be what one could call "earth's (un)ethical final balance or score", humanity is in a position in which all odds stand against its ability to compensate for this gargantuan accumulated pain that billions of species across billions of years were by this ruthless, merciless, careless universe forced to experience in their continual struggle over life and death, all while being mindlessly repeatedly bred into existence, sealing each new animal generation's fate.

I'll make what hopefully will be a self-unfulfilling prediction here of what impending, far into the future delayed calamity is only at most about 1 year away from happening in our future:

Despite the fact that the Outer Space Treaty strictly prohibits risking contamination of celestial bodies, agencies part of countries that subscribed to the Treaty that are active in outer space will - as they always have in the past - ignore this prohibition and don't see why it's more important than even the most severe global extinction events as long as they are merely constrained to earth, and will continue risking and even intending physical contact with celestial bodies of the solar system with contaminated probes which already have been confirmed to have at least temporarily contaminated the moon and Mars - based on official statements e.g. by the administrator of the Science Mission Directorate, John Grunsfeld - and they will not stop there but will forever irreversibly with at extremely fast pace exponentially in their numbers growing microbes contaminate not just any celestial bodies of our solar system but exactly those that very concerningly enable such contamination to have the greatest negative unethical macro-scale consequences, namely the moons Enceladus (with the Enceladus Explorer mission), Europa (with the Europa Lander mission), Ganymede (with the Laplace-P mission), Titan (with the Dragonfly mission), Callisto (with the Gan De mission), and Triton.

What they - because of specialist ethicists and technology assessment groups still not being mandatory for any company projects dealing with novel technology frontiers with foreseeable potential of long-lasting large-scale consequences (like in chemistry, biology, A.I., robotics, and space) - might not know at the time as they are in the process of playing god without telling anyone or asking for international consent or allowing a mass peer-review or global convention and deliberation phase - not unlike to how the story of the sorcerer's apprentice goes who doesn't know how to anymore rid the spirits he summoned - is that the contaminations with (already) multi-cellular microbes risks leading to a by this contamination triggered evolution of life full of dominant suffering of animal wildlife to exist far into the future as possibly billions of years lasting consequence of it, so that anyone messing with celestial bodies incapable of thinking at least that far into the future to account for astronomical scale long-term risks may miss this critical insight.

It is ironic, too, because the discovery of life by means that risk catastrophic contamination may be rewarded by the Nobel Foundation, a foundation that exists because of Nobel's wish to reward accomplishments for the betterment of life, not the worse of it. And understandably, finding extraterrestrial life would be an extraordinary discovery, and so scientists are eager to make such discovery, but aren't reasonably enough restrained in the means they consider for trying to do so, which is a dangerous conception of an incentive structure to have. One thing is for sure: Irreversible contamination of celestial bodies - if it happens - will be a major burden for thousands if not millions of future human generations to come.

Given the globally overall prevailing lack of precautions, preparedness, ethical education and conscientiousness even among scientists, it is also probably just a matter of time until someone's accident while messing with CRISPR will lead to havoc, too, just for humanity having to once more learn about a disaster after an instance of its kind already happened, but at least such a catastrophe would be on a comparably small scope. May future generations of humanity not be mislead by the Peltzman effect compromising their risk behavior.

Here's something I've learned: humans do NOT thrive in utopia. The more problems you solve, the more the still existing problems are blown up into mountains. We can't have this idealistic future unless we change how the human brain works at an extremely fundamental level. We can't do this [waves in the general direction of the optimistic future] as the descendants of wild animals (barring some kind of Borg-like or Unity-like shared consciousness). Thanks for making this video Kurzgesagt. It's really nice to have someone who's not pessimistic about the future. In my eyes and in my heart, I always see tomorrow. I see everything that's not yet to come, and what can be. In my life, I always see infinite sunsets, a horizon with extreme orders of magnitude in potential.

All around me, everyone just refuses or cannot see past the dark. But I always know that past the nightfall, we reach the dawn at our backs. A new rising light on a new world we all have created.

The adversity and issues in our world, they feel quite big. And I don't ever want to trivialize or infantilize the issues that appear in our world. The very real struggles and pains all living things around the globe live and feel.
I'm always looking at the big picture. The curve of progress. The belief in a humanity that wants to make a better world, a better solar system, a better universe.
Over years, decades, centuries. Issues of today that can span a decade, in a zoomed out view of just five hundred years, can seem like they were swatted as fast as swatting an annoying fly.

These things, they feel BIG to us, but they're SMALL comparatively. Humans have made a magnificent amount of progress in such a short amount of time, to the point it's almost enough to make my heart swell with emotion and cry.

When I see videos like this, my heart yearns and cries out for all of those unborn children of the future. Human or not. I want them all to live their tale and to live a beautiful life to them full of meaningful memories.

If you want more details about this, look for Isaac Arthur on YouTube. His channel is all about exploring possible futures, 100% based on hard science, and it's generally very optimistic.
One downside is that after watching through his content, everyone else will seem frustratingly small minded.

While you — as usual — made a fantastic case for this idea, i can't help being a bit worried about where this is going, the idea that this video pushes is sometimes called "long termism", and of course, it doesn't hurt to think about the distant future, and the impact of our choices, but there is a real danger of, in doing so, discounting the present, and in particular, present human lives, as unimprotant, because in the grand scheme of things, they won't matter that much, and that someone (usually very priviledged) in the present doing something that that will matter to people of the future, is incredibly more important than less priviledged people, whose lives will highly likely be of less consequences to that future. This can make you discount even the risk of global warming, because after all, it'll mostly affect poor people and even if humanity will suffer from it, it'll likely survive it, even if a temporary diminution of population is to expect from runaway climate warming. This long termist view is usually held by people who seem more concerned about, say, experimenting with space exploration, than solving real urgent needs of the current humans, when the means they have could certainly make a difference in both, the latter just seem less important when you take the long term view of quattuorquadragintillions of people living through he galaxy over the next trillion years.

So i'm just saying, this idea is to handle with care.

I'd like to challenge one of the (understandable) assumptions that seem to be made in the video. "The last human" needn't be the last member of our lineage. You sort of addressed it when talking about humans modifying themselves. Extinction rates partly account for species no longer present in the fossil record but a good number of them just "evolved away" into new species. For the fossil record that means the branch we assign to the species dying off (because evolution works like that) but that doesn't mean a stopped continuity for that particular species. A lot of those extinct species still had living descendants in other species millions of years later. Same could happen to humans, which both resignifies the meaning of "the last human" (though you caught that one by using "people") and could extend the initial projection of mammal species average time span. We could, in the near future, find ways to modify ourselves as a species to the point that our main branch dies off while the species evolves into something different. It doesn't add much to the point made in the video, but I feel it can bring up the fact that the future can be even more unimaginable than we think.

But my daughter had been vaxxed and we had be vaxxed. She had extremely mild symptoms and one day of harsh fatigue. We didn't isolate her of course. We all wore masks around the house, just hoping to be lucky, but lets be honest, when you're reading your kid bed time stories and she's breathing and sneezing in your face you are going to be exposed. Neither me or my wife have ever tested positive for covid and we test for the safety of others we know who are high risk.

So in the end the worst part of COVID for us, was the year of isolation. It wasn't financially hard. Some might say, "see it was no big deal." I say that it was no big deal because we made damn sure it was going to be no big deal. So many people I talked to weren't worried at all about catching it until I told them our reasoning was that the longer we could avoid it the safer we would be because treatment would get better and possibly even vaccines would be made. We were right. I changed a few minds with that logic. It goes to show just how short sighted humans can be. So many people couldn't think even two years ahead regarding COVID, a new virus that, even now, isn't well understood. It didn't require a whole lot of thought on my part. I just listened to the experts and erred on the side of caution.

I find this perspective (while mathematically optimistic) more interesting when advances in technology are taken into account. Medical and genetic advancements paired with normal evolution means we will likely see drastic changes to what exactly a "human" is, even over the smallest time spans proposed in this video. Expanding even to different planets will likely kickstart evolution for the individuals that live in any ecosystem that is different than their "earthling" ancestors. Much of this change could be performed manually to quickly adapt our physical bodies to our environment. Assuming we eventually hit a computational singularity, the new race of beings that would spawn from an event like that would affect our existence as well, likely either living alongside or merging with the generations to come (partial or complete cybernetic organisms). This would also have drastic influences on our population, allowing us to effectively manufacture "humans" (if we have reached total cyberneticism), or to at least massively alter the lifespan of those that are already alive. That path also brings up the "what is a human" question.

Would love to see a video that focuses on the idea of drastic change in our biology or physical nature in regards to the definition of what a human is. Where are the grey lines? Is a "human" anything that finds its ancestral tree linked with the people that are alive today? There's enough thought content there to fill many books.

Humanity is too stupid to survive.  Nor does it deserve to.

Human ingenuity would negate the negative aspects from early human industialization.  The question of whether humans survive beyond our current epoch concerns tribalism and politics.  If humans are tribal, our politics will not allow us to facilitate sufficient cooperation to make the next leap forward.  The universe has laws for the success of the human species.  Today, we violate those laws.  As a result, we manifest a destiny that will likely lead to our extinction.  Destiny is manifest by actions not aspirations.  The Fermi Paradox is not ever extinguished by any technological advance made by the species.  What we need to do to avoid extinction today is the same humanity that will avoid extinction tomorrow.  If we violate the rules, we die.  If we learn the lessons that lead to success and have the wisdom and discipline to adhere to the winning formula, a descendent of the homo sapien sapien may discover how to extend the life of the universe.  We'll never expand beyond our local group of galaxies, but because of human ingenuity, and because of a innate desire to survive, which is distinct from matter or energy, we may triumph indefinately.

Why do people assume that the birthrate in developed countries is going to always be exactly 2?!!  It almost never is, it's most usually around 1.5, meaning a fast-declining population!  But then you ignore the high-birth rate groups like the Amish, Yiddish, or FLDS that completely violate the demographic transition.  Some groups have succumbed to the demographic transition, like the Hutterites, but then the more conservative groups of Hutterites have started growing faster and replacing other Hutterites.  Apply this to the demographic transition worldwide, and you get a picture of what could soon be the fate of humanity.

humans lasting a million years sounds wildly optimistic to me, not pessimistic.  other species lasted that long because they lived as part of a relatively stable environment that they were generally unable to disrupt in any significant way.  human beings are fundamentally different from that, being smart enough to greatly disrupt that environment that gave rise to them, to their own advantage.  i don't think it means anything to call humanity a "cancer," but the analogy with cancer makes sense to this extent- you can't estimate the life span of a cancer tumor, based on how long the normal tissues of the body generally keep going.  the cancer destroys its host and then dies, much more quickly than the host generally lives without cancer of course.  it may turn out that human beings are smart enough, either to regulate their interactions with the environment that enables them to live, or to expand beyond that environment in an evolutionarily significant way, but how much evidence is there, currently, that they have this kind of potential.

While it feels like current technology, physics, and material science is advancing incredibly fast we may still just be in the "initial discovery" phase as a species. Marveling at the wonders of something new, but entirely ignorant of the true potential when looking at things on the scale of centuries and millennia.

3:40 Let's say for the sake of this comment that each human couple has 4 kids.

YOU save one human

that 1 human gets married and has 4 kids. Those kids have kids, and their children have offspring. Generations continue.

At some point, you will have saved 100+ people just by saving that one person.

Mothers' age is key. If all World women had children very early and very many, the population would grow for example, by up to 4% per year, which means 385 billion people in a hundred years(7.7 * 1.04 ^ 100)!!! But such catastrophe madness will not happen because of the sharp decline in living standards , immediately reduce the life expectancy( most children die early, lack of healthy food and water, education, safety, security, almost no healthcare ). But what happens if women of some different community or country have children early and very many? If we move current and past production to "very early " communities or country, then we will only allow unnaturally accelerated growth of these communities or country.

The point is that if living standards deteriorate somewhere, the population should decline, but shifts the results of production, on the contrary, the deterioration in living standards may even increase population growth.

This should be a real disaster, because there are areas on Earth where not so many people should live, but trade will supply the necessities of life there elsewhere, and population growth will naturally not stop until the whole world is able to generate necessities. so many attempts to try to claim the human race will go big.  Name one invention that humans haven't shot themselves in the foot with. The universe, be it big rip or heat death, will end with nothing we do having mattered save on the trajectory of particles that will never interact with any other particle ever again. Although this is a unique idea about the future of humans, this video is calling for population growth at a similar time that anti-abortion (pro-birth, pro-life) groups in the US are calling for a population growth by removing peoples rights to access safe, medically competent abortions with trained doctors. By saying the unborn are disenfranchised in a way does not acknowledge that there are disenfranchised people all over the world that face poverty, exploitation at work, hunger, disease etc. To ignore this fact, is a similar tactic that anti-abortion (pro-birth, pro-life) groups also use.

Before we focus on our global future, let's focus on the present geo politics that is currently controlling people's ability to choose when and how to have children and whether or not they want to have children.

Calling for population growth as one of our only future possibilities is grossly negligent of our current global reality.

I have a problem with the implied endless growth of human knowledge. A lot of information gets lost over time. Maby we will hit a plateau and stagnate just like the assumed birthrate in the video. The more knowledge we gain the more possibilities we have to lose it again as it gets harder to manage or becomes irrelevant. It's already happening. Just look at how people can't get around without Google maps. (This is not a criticism of these people (including me) btw. ) I know this video is supposed to have an uplifting undertone but it's message becomes falsified when you're making a load of (often necessary) assumptions that fit your narrative while not applying the same rules you just established to other similar aspects. And to be clear: I don't have a problem with this uplifting message. I quite enjoyed it. It just bothers me that it's only based on made up circumstances with napkin calculations to back it up. I hope I'm not being too harsh. I honestly love this channel. I just wanted to voice my opinion.

I don't know if channels like this are willfully ignoring the facts or the people behind them are just mentally lazy. Either way it is a very common type of ignorance. "Far future" and "climate crisis"! What crap! The fact is the very real existential crisis that humanity faces is upon us right now. We are on the verge of a demographic collapse. While the world population is at an all time high the rate of increase actually peaked in 1968! That means we are an aging population. China is the fastest aging nation in history and is on track to have half of its present population by the end of the century. India has been trending down to about two children per couple much like everywhere else in the developing world. Meanwhile in the West there is an absolute cultural and socioeconomic attack on the nuclear family and gender normalcy. Sperm counts continue to fall right along with any meaningful concept of masculinity. What passes for men and women will mostly end up dying alone with their cats! As the Boomers retire and die off there simply is not the population, skill-set, mental stability, work ethic, or common sense to maintain the physical infrastructure of modern civilization. In the decades ahead there will be a tsunami of failed businesses that can't fill necessary positions and institutional and systemic collapses that will render meaningless the phony promises of a prosperous liberal utopia!

Thinking about the vast expanse of time, how the Earth itself is billions of years old, how animals are millions of years into their existence, how even mammals are a part of that multi million year span. And humans... 200000 years. Give or take a few thousand.

Like the video said, we are at the linchpin of determining our existence's longevity. If we're lucky, we get the million year milestone for our species. Rivalling the dominance (by way of asserting our species as the apex) of Earth by the other groups in history, like the dinosaurs. If we play it too fast and loose, we could easily close out our chapter in the Book of Time at not even half a million years. A blip in the timeline of the Earth, much less all existence. Like if a successor species inherits the planet, or even a foreign one finds its here. And they were to study the earth as we did, what manner of sediment layer will represent "The Age of Humans". How thick would 200000-ish years of layers be? But to our credit, we have birthed creations that will cement our presence on this planet until long after we're gone.

I think there is an important missed point here. It is all well and good to try and calculate out how many people might live in the future, and indeed, that is, to a degree, handy to help explain how our future could be optimistic; but it misses something very important: The question is, what is it in human psychology that paints each individual human at the end of the human story, and that is a really important question that is very easy to get wrong, and thus utterly misunderstand why we interact with the world the way we do. We see ourselves at the end of humanity because we are at the end of humanity, since the future is irrelevant as it doesn't exist and we are in the present in our stream of consciousness. This is why the time discount rate can be pretty steep, because delayed gratification has massively diminishing returns. The best hope, then, for long term survival, is figuring out what worked in the past and then replicating it, because old systems that stood the test of time are more useful then experiments in new and unproven ideas. The reason for this should be painfully obvious, our natures are not gonna change any time soon, since they are roughly the same as when we started, so picking system that match our natures is gonna maximize our happiness and well being, and thus improve our odds of survival into the future.

I don't know why everyone always makes future humans the same as the ones now. We are at the birth of biotech. We are only just learning to master biology, and what will be possible in the near future will be mindboggeling. Why do we worry about having gravity in space? Because our biology evolved to work in the presence of gravity. In the future it is entirely probable that we could change our biology to be able to cope without gravity, and potentially even cope with the vacuum of space itself. We may choose to retain our general appearance for aesthetic reasons, but I highly, highly doubt that future humans will be anything like the extremely vulnerable, flawed, and limited animal that we are today, and if the 21st century is to biology what the 20th century was to physics and chemistry, then those changes may come in our own lifetime.

Main things not taken into account. Most developed countries have such a low birthrate of just being slightly over or below 1 that if this projection continues we are already at our population cap. So adding countries becoming developed into the equation birth rates drop unless we say poor countries stay the same, also the UN's projections are that at the point of caping out we will begin to have a drop in population. In Canada, and the USA alone we are expected to see a very noticeable drop in population in just 2 generations unless we have an even larger amount of Immigration. Also using homo erectus as a comparison to how long we may live is wrong, as they didn't die out. As you said they are our ancestors meaning that their linage is still continuing and thus they are still alive in a sense.
Also we already see a massive cap on medical research. If the solution to a problem is found and is very abundant or unable to be easily controlled, then it is not profitable; and in our current economy this means it's tossed out to the wayside until something that can be throttled to raise costs is found.

Evolution never stops. I reckon the last human will be something that we cannot even recognise, many millions or even billions of years in the future.

The problem with the possible gigantic amount of people is that this will only create much more discord, wars and uncertainty. Even with a meager 8 billion people, we are struggling to get along with each other, be it because of race, religion, political ideas, or other. And furthermore, the more humans we have, the harder it will be to communicate with all of them properly across whatever borders we humans will have. This lack of communication and the increasing difficulty of upholding authority will make it a lot more chaotic. This is all because of one big human principle: stubbornness. If someone has a certain ideology, they will do whatever it takes to keep hold of that ideology, no matter what many others say. And whatever progress is made, will also be harder to adopt, again, due to the sheer amount of people we have to distribute it to. And who says these people will even accept it in the first place?

So yes, perhaps we will have more people, but that really doesn't mean all of them will lead a happy existence. But then again, who knows what the future holds?

This really makes the abortion ban in US seem so silly. The argument so many people are using is "Think of how many more people will be born now!"
No, trillions more people will be born in the future anyway. The number one determinant of children's future life success is parental wealth. So, if 100 trillion people will be born, that means 10,000 people will stem from one person, on average. That number rises to 10 quintillion if humans leave the solar system. So, if children aren't forced to be born into poverty, to abuse, to foster care, to teenage parents etc. today; surely, it'd be better for all the 10,000 to 10 quintillion people that stem from that one individual to live happier, more fulfilled lives. To have children when they are actually financially, and socially ready to have children. To increase generational wealth, to reduce adverse childhood experiences. To give all those quintillions of people better lives.
Banning abortion is such a stupid, short-sighted, short-term idea that will only cause harm to people.
If that's the case, that so many people could possibly come from each person alive today. Surely, we should do everything in our power to make life better for everyone. Expand welfare and social housing. Give workers better wages, better hours, better jobs. Expand human rights, abolish poverty, promote racial harmony, stop climate change. Wars seem so silly with this perspective. Like, who even cares about a war about some tiny bit of land in the middle of nowhere. We're destined for so, so much more. And there is plenty to go around.

According to Hindu scriptures and mythology, the universe as we know it is destined to pass through four great epochs, each of which is a complete cycle of cosmic creation and destruction. This divine cycle completes its full-circle at the end of what is known as a Kalpa, or epoch.

Hindu mythology deals with numbers large enough to be nearly impossible to imagine. A Kalpa itself is said to be comprised of a thousand cycles of four yugas, or ages—each of a different quality.

By one estimate, a single yuga cycle is said to be 4.32 million years, and a Kalpa is said to consist of 4.32 billion years

About the Four Yugas
The four great epochs in Hinduism are Satya Yuga, Treta Yuga, Dwapar Yuga and Kali Yuga. Satya Yug or the Age of Truth is said to last for 4,000 divine years, Treta Yuga for 3,000, Dwapara Yug for 2,000 and Kali Yuga will last for 1,000 divine years—a divine year equalling 432,000 earthly years.

Hindu tradition holds that three of these great ages have already passed away, and we are now living in the fourth one—the Kali Yuga. It is quite hard to contemplate the meaning of the vast quantities of time expressed by the Hindu time scheme, so vast are the numbers. There are different theories about the symbolic meaning of these measurements of time.

Symbolic Interpretations
Metaphorically, the four Yuga ages may symbolize the four phases of involution during which man gradually lost the awareness of his inner selves and subtle bodies.

Hinduism believes that human beings have five kinds of bodies, known as annamayakosa, pranamayakosa, manomayakosa vignanamayakosa and anandamayakosa, which respectively mean the “gross body,” the “breath body,” the “psychic body,” the “intelligence body,” and the “bliss body.”

Another theory interprets these epochs of time to represent the degree of loss of righteousness in the world.

This theory suggests that during Satya Yuga, only truth prevailed (Sanskrit Satya = truth). During the Treta Yuga, the universe lost one-fourth of the truth, Dwapar lost one-half of the truth, and now the Kali Yuga is left with only one-fourth of the truth. Evil and dishonesty have therefore gradually replaced truth in the last three ages.

Dasavatara: The 10 Avatars
Throughout these four yugas, Lord Vishnu is said to have been incarnated ten times in ten different avatars. This principle is known as Dasavatara (Sanskrit dasa = ten). During the Age of Truth, human beings were spiritually most advanced and had great psychic powers.

In the Treta Yuga people still remained righteous and adhered to moral ways of life. Lord Rama of the fabled Ramayana lived in Treta Yuga.

In the Dwapara Yuga, men had lost all knowledge of the intelligence and bliss bodies. Lord Krishna was born in this age.

The present Kali Yuga is the most degenerated of the Hindu epochs.

Living in the Kali Yuga
We are said to presently be living in the Kali Yuga—in a world infested with impurities and vices. The numbers of people possessing noble virtues are diminishing day by day. Floods and famine, war and crime, deceit, and duplicity characterize this age.

But, say the scriptures, it is only in this age of critical troubles that final emancipation is possible.

Kali Yuga has two phases: In the first phase, humans—having lost the knowledge of the two higher selves—possessed knowledge of the “breath body” apart from the physical self. Now during the second phase, however, even this knowledge has deserted mankind, leaving us only with the awareness of the gross physical body. This explains why mankind is now more preoccupied with the physical self than any other aspect of existence.

Due to our preoccupation with our physical bodies and our lower selves, and because of our emphasis on the pursuit of gross materialism, this age has been termed the Age of Darkness—an age when we have lost touch with our inner selves, an age of profound ignorance.

What the Scriptures Say
Both the two great epics—The Ramayana and Mahabharata—have spoken about the Kali Yuga.

In the Tulasi Ramayana, we find Kakbhushundi foretelling:

In the Kali Yuga, the hotbed of sin, men and women are all steeped in unrighteousness and act contrary to the Vedas. Every virtue had been engulfed by the sins of Kali Yuga; all good books had disappeared; impostors had promulgated a number of creeds, which they had invented out of their own wit. The people had all fallen prey to delusion and all pious acts had been swallowed by greed.

In the Mahabharata (Santi Parva) Yudhishthir says:

… The ordinances of the Vedas disappear gradually in every successive age, the duties in the Kali age are entirely of another kind. It seems, therefore, that duties have been laid down for the respective age according to the powers of human beings in the respective ages.

The sage Vyasa, later on, clarifies:

In the Kali Yuga, the duties of the respective order disappear and men become afflicted by inequity.

What Happens Next?
According to Hindu cosmology, it is predicted that at the end of the Kali Yuga, Lord Shiva will destroy the universe and the physical body will undergo a great transformation. After the dissolution, Lord Brahma will recreate the universe, and mankind will become the Beings of Truth once again.
